sections.content: Part of Speech: Preposition.

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Evolved from Old English 'be sīdan', literally meaning "by side." It is formed from 'be' ("by") and 'sīde' ("side"). The word's meaning has remained consistently focused on indicating proximity or being next to something since its earliest use.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. The little girl sat beside her mother during the storytelling.
2. He placed his empty coffee cup beside the keyboard.
3. The calm lake stretched beside the winding mountain road.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1. Beside oneself: Overwhelmed with a strong emotion, such as grief, joy, or anger, to the extent of losing self-control or acting irrationally.
2. Beside the point: Irrelevant; not directly related to the main topic or issue being discussed.

title: besides
content:
bɪˈsaɪdz

Pronunciation Key:
/b/ as in "ball"
/ɪ/ as in "sit"
/s/ as in "sit"
/aɪ/ as in "my"
/d/ as in "dog"
/z/ as in "zoo"

1. Preposition: In addition to; apart from.
2. Adverb: Moreover; furthermore; serving to introduce an additional point or reason.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content: Part(s) of Speech: Preposition, Adverb.

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Developed from the Old English 'be sīdan' (see 'beside'), but with the addition of the adverbial genitive '-s' suffix. This suffix often indicated a sense of 'from a place' or 'at a place.' Originally, it could mean "on the side of" or "outside of," which later evolved to convey "in addition to" or "apart from." The distinction in meaning from 'beside' became firmly established over time.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. There's no one here besides us. (Preposition)
2. I don't want to go; besides, it's too late now. (Adverb)
3. She has many talents besides singing. (Preposition)
4. The jacket was too expensive; besides, it wasn't even my style. (Adverb)

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: No widely recognized idioms beyond its direct prepositional and adverbial uses.

title: betray
content:
bɪˈtreɪ

Pronunciation Key:
/b/ as in "ball"
/ɪ/ as in "sit"
/t/ as in "top"
/r/ as in "red"
/eɪ/ as in "day"

1. Verb (Vt): To act disloyally or treacherously towards someone or something, often violating trust or divulging secrets.
2. Verb (Vt): To unintentionally reveal or show signs of something, such as an emotion or truth.
3. Verb (Vt): To expose someone to danger by deceitfully providing information to an opponent or enemy.

details.label: Style
details.value: Common, neutral to formal, often emotionally charged in its first sense.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Verb (transitive, Vt).
Principal parts: betray (base), betrayed (past simple), betrayed (past participle).
Regular verb.

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Comes from Old French 'betraïr' meaning "to betray, deceive." This word was formed by combining the prefix 'be-' (an intensifier or indicating thoroughness) with 'traïr' ("to betray"). 'Traïr' in turn stems from Latin 'trādere' meaning "to hand over, deliver, transmit." The meaning evolved from simply "handing over" to specifically "handing over to an enemy" or "delivering into danger," thus leading to the modern sense of disloyalty and treachery.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. He felt deeply hurt when his best friend betrayed his confidence.
2. Her nervous fidgeting betrayed her true feelings about the situation.
3. The spy was captured after his contact betrayed him to the authorities.
4. His silence betrayed his agreement with the plan.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1. Betray a secret: To reveal confidential information, usually inadvertently or due to a breach of trust.
2. Betray a trust: To violate confidence or loyalty placed in one by another.

title: bias
content:
ˈbaɪəs

Pronunciation Key:
/b/ as in "ball"
/aɪ/ as in "my"
/ə/ as in "about" (schwa)
/s/ as in "sit"

1. Noun: A strong inclination or prejudice for or against one thing, person, or group compared with another, often considered unfair.
2. Noun: A diagonal line or cut across the weave of a fabric, allowing for better drape.
3. Verb (Vt): To cause to have a bias; to influence unfairly.

details.label: Style
details.value: Common, neutral, can be formal or technical depending on context.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part(s) of Speech: Noun, Verb (transitive, Vt).
Noun plural: biases
Verb principal parts: bias (base), biased (past simple), biased (past participle).
Regular verb.

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Originates from Old French 'biais' meaning "slant, slope, oblique." The ultimate root is Proto-Indo-European '*h₂eh₃-' ("to be inclined"). The word first appeared in English in the 15th century, referring to a literal 'slant' or 'oblique line.' The figurative sense of 'predisposition' or 'prejudice' developed in the 16th century, likely influenced by the game of bowls, where a 'bias' referred to a weight in the bowl that caused it to swerve from a straight path.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. The judge was accused of bias towards the defendant. (Noun)
2. Cutting fabric on the bias allows it to drape more smoothly. (Noun)
3. The news report was clearly biased against the new policy. (Verb past participle used as adjective)
4. His personal experiences bias his view on the subject. (Verb)

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1. Confirmation bias: The psychological tendency to search for, interpret, favor, and recall information in a way that confirms one's pre-existing beliefs or hypotheses.
2. Bias cut: A method of cutting fabric diagonally across the grain, often used in dressmaking for a softer drape.

title: bid
content:
bɪd

Pronunciation Key:
/b/ as in "ball"
/ɪ/ as in "sit"
/d/ as in "dog"

1. Verb (Vt/Vi): To offer a specific amount of money for something, especially at an auction, or for a contract or project.
2. Verb (Vt): To command or order (archaic or literary use).
3. Verb (Vt): To express a greeting, farewell, or wish to someone (archaic or literary use).
4. Noun: An offer of a price, especially at an auction or for a commercial contract.
5. Noun: An attempt or effort to achieve something.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part(s) of Speech: Verb (transitive Vt, intransitive Vi), Noun.
Verb principal parts (for offering price): bid (base), bid (past simple), bid (past participle). (Irregular)
Verb principal parts (for archaic meaning "command/greet"): bid (base), bade (past simple), bidden (past participle). (Irregular)
Noun plural: bids

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Derives from Old English 'biddan' meaning "to ask, entreat, pray, beg." This comes from Proto-Germanic '*bidjaną' ("to ask, pray"), which has its roots in Proto-Indo-European '*bʰedʰ-' ("to dig, penetrate," perhaps leading to "to ask, entreat" via the idea of 'forcing through'). The modern sense of "offering a price" emerged in the 16th century, developing from the concept of "asking" someone to accept a proposed price. The irregular past tense forms 'bade'/'bidden' are generally reserved for the older, archaic meanings of commanding or greeting, while the sense of 'offering a price' typically uses 'bid, bid, bid'.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. She bid $500 for the antique vase at the auction. (Verb)
2. The company placed a competitive bid for the construction project. (Noun)
3. They are making a bid to host the next Olympic Games. (Noun)
4. He bid farewell to his family before embarking on his journey. (Verb, archaic/literary)

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1. Do one's bidding: To obey someone's commands or instructions.
2. Bid farewell/goodbye: To say goodbye to someone.
3. Bid for power: To make an attempt or effort to gain control or influence.

title: bind
content:
baɪnd

Pronunciation Key:
/b/ as in "ball"
/aɪ/ as in "my"
/n/ as in "now"
/d/ as in "dog"

1. Verb (Vt): To tie or fasten something tightly, typically with rope, string, or another material.
2. Verb (Vt): To unite or hold together, often by means of obligation, affection, or a shared experience.
3. Verb (Vt): To impose a duty, obligation, or restriction upon someone or something.
4. Verb (Vt): To secure pages into a book format by means of glue or stitching.
5. Noun: A difficult, restrictive, or awkward situation.

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Fastening, obligation, unity, restriction, books, difficulties

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part(s) of Speech: Verb (transitive Vt), Noun.
Verb principal parts: bind (base), bound (past simple), bound (past participle). (Irregular)
Noun plural: binds

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Originates from Old English 'bindan' meaning "to bind, tie up, fetter, make captive." This word is derived from Proto-Germanic '*bindaną' ("to bind"), which itself traces back to Proto-Indo-European '*bʰendʰ-' ("to bind"). It shares cognates with words like German 'binden' and Dutch 'binden'. The fundamental meaning of tying or fastening has remained central, extending metaphorically over time to include concepts of obligations, unity, and restriction.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. She used a rope to bind the package securely. (Verb)
2. Their shared experiences bound them together as lifelong friends. (Verb)
3. The contract will bind both parties to the agreed terms. (Verb)
4. The old bookbinder could bind even the most delicate manuscripts. (Verb)
5. The company found itself in a real bind after the sudden market crash. (Noun)

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1. Bound to: Certain or destined to do something; very likely to happen.
2. Bind up: To bandage or wrap a wound or injury.
3. Bind oneself to: To commit oneself to an agreement, promise, or course of action.
4. In a bind: In a difficult, problematic, or awkward situation that restricts one's options.

title: biography
content:
baɪˈɒɡrəfi/ (British English), /baɪˈɑːɡrəfi/ (American English)

Pronunciation Key:
/b/ as in "ball"
/aɪ/ as in "my"
/ɒ/ as in "hot" (British English)
/ɑː/ as in "father" (American English)
/ɡ/ as in "go"
/r/ as in "red"
/ə/ as in "about" (schwa)
/f/ as in "fan"
/i/ as in "fleece"

1. Noun: A detailed written account of a person's life, typically written by someone other than the subject.

details.label: Style
details.value: Common, neutral, often used in academic or literary contexts.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Noun.
Plural: biographies

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Coined in the 17th century from New Latin 'biographia', which itself was formed from Ancient Greek 'bios' (βίος) meaning "life" and 'graphia' (γραφία) meaning "writing." Thus, the word literally means "life writing," precisely reflecting its modern definition.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. She spent years researching before writing the comprehensive biography of the famous artist.
2. His new biography reveals many previously unknown details about the president's early life.
3. Reading a biography can offer valuable insights into historical periods.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: No widely recognized idioms or fixed phrases.

title: biological
content:
bɪɒˈlɒdʒɪkəl

Pronunciation Key:
/b/ as in `bat`
/ɪ/ as in `kit`
/ɒ/ as in `lot` (BrE), /ɑː/ as in `father` (AmE)
/ˈlɒdʒ/ as in `lodge` (BrE), /ˈlɑːdʒ/ as in `large` (AmE)
/ɪkəl/ as in `local` without the `o`

1.  **Adjective:** Relating to living organisms, their life processes, or biology as a scientific field. It concerns anything that is alive or has once been alive, including plants, animals, and microorganisms, and the systems or substances derived from them.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Adjective
Comparative: more biological
Superlative: most biological

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
The word 'biological' entered English in the late 18th century, formed by adding the suffix '-ical' to 'biology'.
'Biology' itself was coined in the early 19th century from combining Greek `bios` (life) and `logia` (the study of, a branch of learning). Therefore, 'biological' fundamentally means 'pertaining to the study of life'.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The scientist discovered a new biological process in the plant's cells.
2.  We need to understand the biological factors that contribute to the disease.
3.  Humans have a biological need for sleep and nourishment.
4.  The museum exhibit included models of various biological systems.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: No common idioms or fixed phrases use 'biological' in a distinct, non-literal sense. It is typically used in a direct, scientific context.

title: bishop
content:
ˈbɪʃəp

Pronunciation Key:
/ˈbɪʃ/ as in `fish` but with a `b`
/əp/ as in `cup`

1.  **Noun:** A high-ranking clergyman, typically in Christian churches, who is responsible for overseeing a diocese or a group of local churches. They hold significant spiritual and administrative authority.
2.  **Noun:** A chess piece, typically depicted as a miter, which moves diagonally any number of squares of the same color.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Noun
Plural: bishops

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The word 'bishop' comes from Old English `bisċeop`, which in turn originated from Late Latin `episcopus`. This Latin term was borrowed from Greek `episkopos` (overseer, guardian). The Greek word is a compound of `epi-` (over) and `skopos` (watcher, one who looks). The evolution reflects the role of a bishop as one who 'oversees' or 'watches over' a congregation or diocese. The chess piece is named for its visual resemblance to a bishop's traditional headwear (miter).

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The bishop addressed the congregation during the Sunday service.
2.  She hopes to become a bishop in the Anglican Church someday.
3.  In chess, the bishop is a powerful piece on the open board.
4.  He moved his bishop to attack the opponent's knight.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: No common idioms or fixed phrases specifically use 'bishop' in a non-literal sense beyond its direct religious or chess meanings.

title: bizarre
content:
bɪˈzɑː

Pronunciation Key:
/bɪ/ as in `bit` but with `i` as in `machine`
/ˈzɑː/ as in `star` but with a `z`

1.  **Adjective:** Extremely strange, unusual, or unconventional, often in a way that is strikingly odd or peculiar.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Adjective
Comparative: more bizarre
Superlative: most bizarre

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The word 'bizarre' entered English in the mid-17th century directly from French `bizarre`, meaning 'odd, fantastic'. The French word's origin is uncertain but likely comes from Italian `bizzarro` (irascible, strange, whimsical). Some theories trace it further back to Basque `bizar` (beard), suggesting an original meaning of 'bearded' or 'manly' which then evolved to 'fierce' and eventually 'strange' or 'unusual'.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The artist created a truly bizarre sculpture from recycled materials.
2.  We heard a bizarre story about a talking cat that lives next door.
3.  Her outfit for the party was so bizarre that everyone stared.
4.  The entire situation felt too bizarre to be real.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: No common idioms or fixed phrases use 'bizarre'.

title: blade
content:
bleɪd

Pronunciation Key:
/bl/ as in `blue`
/eɪ/ as in `day`
/d/ as in `dog`

1.  **Noun:** The flat, sharp, cutting part of a knife, sword, or other tool or weapon.
2.  **Noun:** A single flat piece forming part of a device that rotates, such as a propeller, fan, or turbine.
3.  **Noun:** A broad, flat leaf of grass or a similar plant like corn.
4.  **Noun:** The broad, flat part of an oar or paddle.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Noun
Plural: blades

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The word 'blade' comes from Old English `blæd` (leaf, foil, blade). It is related to Old High German `blat` and Old Norse `blað`, all deriving from Proto-Germanic `*bladaz` (leaf, foliage). The meaning evolved from a simple leaf to the flat part of a tool or weapon, then to rotating parts, reflecting a common characteristic of flatness or thinness.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  Be careful when handling the knife; its blade is extremely sharp.
2.  The helicopter's blades spun rapidly, lifting it off the ground.
3.  He pulled a single blade of grass and chewed on it thoughtfully.
4.  The canoeist dug the paddle's blade deep into the water.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1.  **Blade of grass:** A single piece of grass (common usage, not strictly idiomatic but a fixed phrase).
2.  **To turn a blind eye:** (Incorrect. This is for 'blind', not 'blade'). No common idioms for 'blade'.

title: blanket
content:
ˈblæŋkɪt

Pronunciation Key:
/ˈblæŋ/ as in `bang` but with `l`
/kɪt/ as in `kit`

1.  **Noun:** A large piece of soft cloth, typically rectangular, used for warmth, especially as a covering on a bed or for snuggling.
2.  **Noun:** A thick layer or covering of something, often spread out over an area.
3.  **Verb (Vt):** To cover completely with a thick layer of something.
4.  **Verb (Vt):** To apply to or include a wide range of situations, people, or things, often without discrimination.

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Textiles, Household Items, Weather, Covering, Inclusion

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Noun, Verb

**Noun:**
Plural: blankets

**Verb:**
Base: blanket
Past Simple: blanketed
Past Participle: blanketed
Type: Transitive (Vt)
Regular verb

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The word 'blanket' entered English in the late 14th century, from Old French `blanchet`, a diminutive of `blanc` (white), referring to a type of white woolen fabric used for coverings. The name originally denoted the color of the wool often used for such items. Its usage as a verb emerged in the 17th century, drawing directly from the noun's meaning of 'covering'.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  She pulled the warm blanket up to her chin as the temperature dropped.
2.  A thick blanket of snow covered the entire landscape overnight.
3.  The fog blanketed the entire valley, reducing visibility to almost zero.
4.  The new policy will blanket all employees, regardless of their department.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1.  **Wet blanket:** A person who discourages enjoyment or enthusiasm by being dull or pessimistic.
2.  **Security blanket:** An object, often a soft toy or piece of cloth, that a child uses for comfort and security; by extension, anything that provides a sense of security.
3.  **Throw a wet blanket on (something):** To spoil or dampen an activity or enthusiasm.

title: blast
content:
blɑːst (BrE) / blæst (AmE)

Pronunciation Key:
/b/ as in `bat`
/l/ as in `light`
/ɑː/ as in `father` (BrE long `a`)
/æ/ as in `cat` (AmE short `a`)
/s/ as in `sit`
/t/ as in `top`

1.  **Noun:** A sudden, powerful rush of air or sound, often accompanied by strong force.
2.  **Noun:** An explosion, or the destructive effect of an explosion.
3.  **Verb (Vt/Vi):** To produce a very loud sound, often deliberately with music or noise.
4.  **Verb (Vt):** To destroy, break apart, or propel something with an explosive force or powerful jet.
5.  **Verb (Vt):** To criticize someone or something very severely.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Noun, Verb

**Noun:**
Plural: blasts

**Verb:**
Base: blast
Past Simple: blasted
Past Participle: blasted
Type: Transitive (Vt) and Intransitive (Vi)
Regular verb

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The word 'blast' originates from Old English `blæst` (a blowing, a gust of wind). This in turn comes from Proto-Germanic `*blas-` (to blow). Over time, the meaning expanded from simply a strong wind to any powerful release, such as sound or an explosion, and then metaphorically to powerful criticism or intense enjoyment.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  A cold blast of wind hit us as we opened the door.
2.  The miners used dynamite to blast away the rock.
3.  He likes to blast his music through giant speakers.
4.  Critics blasted the new government policy.
5.  The rocket prepared for its final blast off.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1.  **Have a blast:** To have a lot of fun; to enjoy oneself greatly.
2.  **Blast off:** (Of a rocket or spacecraft) to take off from the ground.
3.  **Full blast:** At maximum power or speed.
4.  **Blast from the past:** Something or someone that unexpectedly reminds one of the past.

title: bleed
content:
bliːd

Pronunciation Key:
/b/ as in `bat`
/l/ as in `light`
/iː/ as in `sheep` (long `ee` sound)
/d/ as in `dog`

1.  **Verb (Vi/Vt):** To lose blood from the body, typically from a wound or internal injury.
2.  **Verb (Vi):** (Of a color) to run or spread into an adjacent area, especially when wet.
3.  **Verb (Vi):** To be forced to pay or give up money or resources excessively, often over time.
4.  **Verb (Vt):** To draw liquid, air, or gas from a system or container, typically to release pressure or unwanted elements.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Verb

Base: bleed
Past Simple: bled
Past Participle: bled
Type: Intransitive (Vi) and Transitive (Vt)
Irregular verb

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The word 'bleed' comes from Old English `blēdan` (to bleed), which is derived from the Proto-Germanic `*blōþjanan` (to cause to bleed), itself related to `*blōþą` (blood). The meaning has broadened over time to include any 'oozing' or 'draining' of liquid or resources, conceptually linked to the loss of blood.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  His arm started to bleed after he cut it on the sharp edge.
2.  The red dye in the new shirt might bleed onto lighter clothes in the wash.
3.  The constant fees were bleeding the small business dry.
4.  The mechanic had to bleed the brakes to ensure they worked properly.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1.  **Bleed someone dry:** To take all of someone's money or resources.
2.  **My heart bleeds for you:** An expression of mock sympathy or pity, often sarcastic.
3.  **Bleed blue/red/etc.:** To be a very loyal supporter of a team or organization, often associated with their colors.
4.  **Bleeding edge:** The very forefront of technological development; extremely new and often unproven.

title: blend
content:
blend

Pronunciation Key:
/b/ as in `bat`
/l/ as in `light`
/e/ as in `bed`
/n/ as in `nap`
/d/ as in `dog`

1.  **Verb (Vt/Vi):** To mix two or more substances together thoroughly so that they combine and often lose their individual characteristics.
2.  **Verb (Vi):** To combine harmoniously or imperceptibly with something else; to merge or integrate seamlessly.
3.  **Noun:** A mixture or combination of different things, especially one that is made to be well-combined or harmonious.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Verb, Noun

**Verb:**
Base: blend
Past Simple: blended (also `blent`, archaic/literary)
Past Participle: blended (also `blent`, archaic/literary)
Type: Transitive (Vt) and Intransitive (Vi)
Regular verb (though `blent` exists as an archaic irregular form)

**Noun:**
Plural: blends

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The word 'blend' emerged in English in the 16th century, thought to be from Old Norse `blanda` (to mix). This, in turn, comes from Proto-Germanic `*blandanan` (to mix). The term has consistently referred to the act or result of combining things, evolving slightly in its application but retaining its core meaning of mixture and integration.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  She likes to blend fresh fruits and vegetables into her morning smoothie.
2.  The new building's design blends seamlessly with the historic architecture of the neighborhood.
3.  The artist used different shades of blue to create a smooth blend in the sky.
4.  This coffee is a special blend of beans from various regions.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: 1.  **Blend in:** To be inconspicuous or conform to one's surroundings, so as not to stand out.

title: bless
content:
bles

Pronunciation Key:
/b/ as in `bat`
/l/ as in `light`
/e/ as in `bed`
/s/ as in `sit`

1.  **Verb (Vt):** To express approval, support, or good wishes for someone or something, often in a religious or spiritual context, or to invoke divine favor upon them.
2.  **Verb (Vt):** To make something holy or sacred, often through a religious ceremony.
3.  **Verb (Vt):** To endow or provide with a desirable or advantageous quality or gift, often implying a natural or divine origin.
4.  **Verb (Vi):** (Usually in exclamation) To express surprise, mild anger, or pity.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Verb

Base: bless
Past Simple: blessed (also `blest`, poetic/archaic)
Past Participle: blessed (also `blest`, poetic/archaic)
Type: Transitive (Vt) and Intransitive (Vi)
Regular verb (though `blest` exists as an archaic irregular form)

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The word 'bless' comes from Old English `blētsian` or `blēdsian`, meaning 'to consecrate with blood, mark with blood, hallow'. This is thought to be derived from `blōd` (blood), possibly referring to pagan sacrificial rituals. However, it was reinterpreted early on by Christian missionaries to mean 'to consecrate, make holy', often by invoking God's favor. The meaning evolved from a physical act of consecration to a spiritual one, then to general good wishes or fortunate endowment.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The priest will bless the newlyweds at the end of the ceremony.
2.  May God bless you and keep you safe on your journey.
3.  She was blessed with a beautiful singing voice.
4.  Well, bless my soul, I never expected to see you here!

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1.  **God bless America/you/etc.:** A common expression of good wishes, patriotism, or sometimes mild surprise.
2.  **Bless your heart:** (Often in the American South) Can be a genuine expression of sympathy or affection, but can also be used condescendingly to mean 'you're naive' or 'you're foolish'.
3.  **Bless me (or my soul):** An exclamation of surprise or astonishment.
4.  **Bless you!:** Said after someone sneezes (traditionally to ward off evil or simply out of polite custom).

title: blessing
content:
ˈblesɪŋ

Pronunciation Key:
/ˈbles/ as in `less` but with `b`
/ɪŋ/ as in `sing`

1.  **Noun:** A divine favor or gift; something that brings happiness, benefit, or good fortune.
2.  **Noun:** A prayer or invocation asking for divine favor or protection.
3.  **Noun:** The act of consecrating or making something holy.
4.  **Noun:** Approval or encouragement for an action or undertaking.

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Religion, Spirituality, Good Fortune, Approval, Gratitude

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Noun
Plural: blessings

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The word 'blessing' evolved from Old English `blētsung`, meaning 'consecration, the act of blessing'. It is directly related to the verb 'bless', sharing its etymological path from an Old English word associated with blood rituals, which was later reinterpreted in a Christian context to mean divine favor or consecration. The suffix '-ing' denotes a noun formed from a verb, signifying either the action or the result of the action.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The birth of their child was truly a blessing to the family.
2.  Before the meal, the family said a blessing together.
3.  The bishop gave his blessing to the newly built church.
4.  She asked for her parents' blessing before accepting the job overseas.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1.  **A blessing in disguise:** Something that initially seems like a misfortune but turns out to be beneficial.
2.  **Count your blessings:** To be grateful for the good things in one's life, especially when facing difficulties.
3.  **The blessing of the Lord:** A phrase referring to divine favor or grace.

title: blow
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /bloʊ/

Pronunciation Key: /b/ as in 'bed', /l/ as in 'light', /oʊ/ as in 'boat'.

**Meaning 1 (Verb, Air Movement):** To expel air forcefully from the mouth, or for air/wind to move something or someone.

**Meaning 2 (Verb, Impact):** To strike something or someone with force, often with a hand or object.

**Meaning 3 (Verb, Opportunity/Money):** To waste or squander an opportunity or a sum of money.

**Meaning 4 (Noun, Impact):** A forceful hit or strike, typically delivered with a hand or an object.

**Meaning 5 (Noun, Air Movement):** A strong, often sudden, current of air or wind.

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Air, Force, Movement, Opportunity, Finance, Emotion

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
**Verb:**
  * Base: blow
  * Past Simple: blew
  * Past Participle: blown
  * Type: Transitive (Vt) and Intransitive (Vi) (Irregular verb)

**Noun:**
  * Plural: blows

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
The verb `blow` (meaning air movement) derives from Old English `blāwan` 'to blow, breathe', which comes from Proto-Germanic `*blēaną`, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European `*bʰleh₁-` 'to swell, blow'.

The sense of 'to strike' or 'a stroke' (as a noun) evolved from the idea of delivering a 'blow' or a 'puff' of air, by extension becoming a forceful impact, around the 14th century.

The sense of 'to squander' (money/opportunity) developed in the 19th century, likely stemming from the idea of 'blowing away' or causing something to vanish.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. He took a deep breath and blew out the candles on his birthday cake.
2. The strong wind blew down several trees during the storm.
3. The boxer delivered a powerful blow to his opponent's jaw.
4. You really shouldn't blow all your savings on frivolous items.
5. Don't blow this chance to prove yourself; it's a rare opportunity.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
*   **blow off steam:** To release pent-up energy, anger, or frustration, often through physical activity or talking.
*   **blow up:** To explode; to inflate; to become very angry.
*   **blow someone's mind:** To impress or astound someone greatly; to cause a profound mental effect.
*   **blow hot and cold:** To be indecisive or inconsistent, constantly changing one's opinion or attitude.
*   **blow a fuse:** To lose one's temper suddenly and intensely.

title: boast
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /boʊst/

Pronunciation Key: /b/ as in 'bed', /oʊ/ as in 'boat', /s/ as in 'sun', /t/ as in 'top'.

**Meaning 1 (Verb):** To speak about one's own achievements, possessions, or abilities with excessive pride or self-satisfaction.

**Meaning 2 (Verb):** To possess a feature or quality that is a source of pride or advantage.

**Meaning 3 (Noun):** A statement or act that expresses excessive pride, especially about oneself.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
**Verb:**
  * Base: boast
  * Past Simple: boasted
  * Past Participle: boasted
  * Type: Transitive (Vt) and Intransitive (Vi) (Regular verb)

**Noun:**
  * Plural: boasts

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The word `boast` (verb and noun) entered English in the Middle English period, around the 13th century, as `bost`. Its ultimate origin is uncertain but likely either from an Old French word `boste` meaning 'swelling' (suggesting inflated talk) or from a Germanic root. It is not directly connected to the Old English word `bōst` (meaning 'buttress').

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. He constantly boasts about how much money he makes.
2. The small town boasts a beautiful historic church.
3. Her claim to have completed the marathon in under three hours was no idle boast.
4. She never boasts about her intelligence, preferring to let her work speak for itself.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: *   **not much to boast about:** Something that is not particularly impressive or worthy of pride; rather ordinary or disappointing.

title: bold
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /boʊld/

Pronunciation Key: /b/ as in 'bed', /oʊ/ as in 'boat', /l/ as in 'light', /d/ as in 'dog'.

**Meaning 1 (Adjective, Courageous):** Showing courage, confidence, and a willingness to take risks; not hesitating or fearful.

**Meaning 2 (Adjective, Appearance):** Clearly visible or standing out prominently; striking in appearance.

**Meaning 3 (Adjective, Printing):** Referring to typeface that is thicker and darker than normal, used for emphasis.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
**Adjective:**
  * Positive: bold
  * Comparative: bolder
  * Superlative: boldest

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The word `bold` comes from Old English `bald` 'courageous, strong, brave'. This in turn derives from Proto-Germanic `*balþaz`. The meaning evolved to include 'prominent' or 'striking' in the 17th century, influenced by the idea of something standing out confidently. The typographical sense emerged in the 18th century as a literal representation of 'standing out'.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. It was a bold decision to invest everything in the new startup.
2. The artist used bold strokes of red and blue in her abstract painting.
3. She made a bold statement about her political beliefs at the conference.
4. Please make sure the main headings are in **bold** type.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: *   **bold as brass:** Extremely confident and often impudent or disrespectful.

title: bombing
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /ˈbɒmɪŋ/ (UK), /ˈbɑːmɪŋ/ (US)

Pronunciation Key: /b/ as in 'bed', /ɒ/ as in 'lot' (UK) or /ɑː/ as in 'father' (US), /m/ as in 'mat', /ɪ/ as in 'kit', /ŋ/ as in 'sing'.

**Meaning 1 (Noun, Military/Attack):** The act of attacking a target with bombs, or a specific instance of such an attack, especially from the air.

**Meaning 2 (Noun, Informal/Failure):** A complete failure or disaster, particularly in the context of a performance, event, or product.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
**Noun:**
  * Plural: bombings
  * `bombing` is also the present participle and gerund of the verb `bomb`.

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: `Bombing` is the gerund and present participle of the verb `bomb`. The verb `bomb` entered English in the late 17th century, referring to projectile weapons. It comes from French `bombe`, which in turn is from Italian `bomba`. The ultimate origin is likely onomatopoeic, imitating the sound of an explosion. The informal sense of 'failure' is a more recent development, emerging in the mid-20th century, likely from the idea of something 'blowing up' or failing spectacularly.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. The city suffered severe damage from the constant bombing during the war.
2. An international team is investigating the recent terrorist bombing.
3. Despite high expectations, the new movie turned out to be a complete bombing at the box office.
4. The stand-up comedian was a bombing, barely getting any laughs.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: *   (No widely recognized idioms specific to the noun 'bombing' outside of its direct meanings or derived from the verb 'bomb' which often forms phrasal verbs like 'bomb out' meaning to fail.)

title: bonus
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /ˈboʊnəs/

Pronunciation Key: /b/ as in 'bed', /oʊ/ as in 'boat', /n/ as in 'nap', /ə/ as in 'about', /s/ as in 'sun'.

**Meaning 1 (Noun, Reward):** An extra payment, reward, or benefit given in addition to what is normally expected or required, often as an incentive or recognition of performance.

**Meaning 2 (Noun, Advantage):** An unexpected or additional advantage or benefit.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
**Noun:**
  * Plural: bonuses

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The word `bonus` was adopted into English in the mid-18th century. It comes directly from Latin `bonus`, meaning 'good'. Originally an adjective, its use as a noun for an extra payment or benefit developed in the financial context, often referring to dividends or extra payments to shareholders or employees, reflecting the idea of something 'good' being added.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. The top sales performers received a generous year-end bonus.
2. Finding a parking spot right in front of the building was an unexpected bonus.
3. The company offered a sign-on bonus to attract new talent.
4. Having a swimming pool in the backyard is a real bonus for summer.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: *   (No widely recognized idioms specific to the word 'bonus'.)

title: booking
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /ˈbʊkɪŋ/

Pronunciation Key: /b/ as in 'bed', /ʊ/ as in 'book', /k/ as in 'cat', /ɪ/ as in 'kit', /ŋ/ as in 'sing'.

**Meaning 1 (Noun, Reservation):** An arrangement made in advance to reserve a place, service, or event, such as a flight, hotel room, or theatre ticket.

**Meaning 2 (Noun, Legal/Police):** The official act of recording a person's name and details as part of an arrest process or for a specific offense.

**Meaning 3 (Noun, Sports):** A formal caution or disciplinary action given to a player by a referee, typically involving a written record (e.g., a yellow card in soccer).

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
**Noun:**
  * Plural: bookings
  * `booking` is also the present participle and gerund of the verb `book`.

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: `Booking` is the gerund and present participle of the verb `book`. The verb `book` traces back to Old English `bōcian` 'to make a written record, to register, to grant by charter'. This is related to `bōc` 'book', referring to written tablets. The meaning expanded to include reserving something by making a record of it (19th century). The police and sports senses developed later from the idea of recording an offense.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. We have a dinner booking at 7 PM at the new restaurant.
2. All flight bookings must be confirmed at least 24 hours in advance.
3. After the altercation, the suspect was taken to the station for booking.
4. The referee gave the player a booking for a dangerous tackle.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: *   (No widely recognized idioms specific to the noun 'booking'.)

title: boom
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /buːm/

Pronunciation Key: /b/ as in 'bed', /uː/ as in 'moon', /m/ as in 'mat'.

**Meaning 1 (Noun, Sound):** A deep, resonant, and often loud sound, typically sudden.

**Meaning 2 (Verb, Sound):** To make a deep, resonant sound; to speak with a loud, deep voice.

**Meaning 3 (Noun, Economy):** A period of rapid and significant economic growth, prosperity, or increase in activity.

**Meaning 4 (Verb, Economy):** To experience or cause rapid growth or prosperity.

**Meaning 5 (Noun, Structure):** A long pole or beam, often used to extend or support something, such as on a sailboat to extend the foot of a sail or on a crane.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
**Verb:**
  * Base: boom
  * Past Simple: boomed
  * Past Participle: boomed
  * Type: Transitive (Vt) and Intransitive (Vi) (Regular verb)

**Noun:**
  * Plural: booms

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
**For meanings related to sound (Noun, Verb):** The word `boom` is onomatopoeic, first appearing in the 15th century, directly imitating the sound it describes.

**For meanings related to economic growth (Noun, Verb):** This sense emerged in the mid-19th century, possibly from the sound of rapid expansion, or from the rapid motion suggested by the nautical 'boom'.

**For meanings related to a long pole/structure (Noun):** This sense comes from Middle Dutch `boom` (and similar words in Low German), meaning 'tree, pole, beam'. This shares a common Germanic root with words like German `Baum` (tree) and Old English `beam` (tree, timber).

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. We heard the distant boom of fireworks echoing through the valley.
2. His powerful voice boomed across the large auditorium, filling the space.
3. The region experienced an unprecedented economic boom in the late 1990s.
4. The crane's long boom extended high into the sky to lift the heavy steel beam.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: *   **boom and bust:** A descriptive phrase for a recurring cycle in economics involving periods of rapid growth followed by periods of decline or contraction.

title: boost
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /buːst/

Pronunciation Key: /b/ as in 'bed', /uː/ as in 'moon', /s/ as in 'sun', /t/ as in 'top'.

**Meaning 1 (Verb):** To help something to increase, improve, or become more successful; to provide support for an upward movement.

**Meaning 2 (Noun):** An act of helping or encouraging an increase or improvement; an instance of pushing or lifting upward.

**Meaning 3 (Verb, Informal):** To steal something.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
**Verb:**
  * Base: boost
  * Past Simple: boosted
  * Past Participle: boosted
  * Type: Transitive (Vt) (Regular verb)

**Noun:**
  * Plural: boosts

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The word `boost` emerged in American English in the mid-19th century, first as a verb meaning 'to lift up'. Its exact origin is uncertain, but it may be related to words like Middle English `boust` 'to lift' or `bost` 'a blow' (perhaps implying a forceful lift). The figurative sense of 'to help improve' or 'increase' developed shortly thereafter. The informal meaning 'to steal' is a more recent, slang development from the early 20th century.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. The new advertising campaign aims to boost product sales significantly.
2. Winning the competition gave her confidence a much-needed boost.
3. Can you give me a boost so I can reach the top shelf?
4. The police caught him trying to boost car parts from the garage.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: *   **boost morale:** To improve the spirits and confidence of a group or individual.

title: bounce
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /baʊns/

Pronunciation Key: /b/ as in 'bed', /aʊ/ as in 'mouth', /n/ as in 'nap', /s/ as in 'sun'.

**Meaning 1 (Verb, Movement):** To spring back or rebound after hitting a surface; to move up and down repeatedly.

**Meaning 2 (Noun, Movement):** An act of springing back, rebounding, or moving with elasticity.

**Meaning 3 (Noun, Quality):** The quality of elasticity or resilience, allowing something to spring back.

**Meaning 4 (Verb, Informal):** To leave a place quickly; to be rejected (e.g., a check due to insufficient funds).

**Meaning 5 (Noun, Informal):** Liveliness, energy, or resilience.

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Movement, Energy, Recovery, Elasticity, Finance (informal), Social Interaction (informal)

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
**Verb:**
  * Base: bounce
  * Past Simple: bounced
  * Past Participle: bounced
  * Type: Transitive (Vt) and Intransitive (Vi) (Regular verb)

**Noun:**
  * Plural: bounces

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The word `bounce` entered English in the Middle English period, around the 14th century, as `bounsen`. Its exact origin is somewhat uncertain, but it may have come from Middle Dutch `bonsen` 'to beat, thump, strike', or from an imitative Germanic root related to striking or leaping. The sense of a check 'bouncing' (being returned unpaid) developed in the early 20th century, and the informal sense of 'leaving quickly' emerged later in the same century.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. The rubber ball will bounce high if you throw it hard.
2. She had a cheerful bounce in her step as she walked away.
3. The bad check caused my account to bounce, incurring fees.
4. I need to bounce some ideas off my colleagues before finalizing the plan.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
*   **bounce back:** To recover quickly from a setback, illness, or difficulty.
*   **bounce off the walls:** To be extremely energetic, restless, or excited, often to the point of being uncontrollable.
*   **bounce ideas off someone:** To discuss ideas with someone in order to get their feedback or opinion.

title: bound
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /baʊnd/

Pronunciation Key: /b/ as in 'bed', /aʊ/ as in 'mouth', /n/ as in 'nap', /d/ as in 'dog'.

**Meaning 1 (Verb, Movement):** To move quickly by leaping or springing, often with long, energetic strides.

**Meaning 2 (Noun, Movement):** A single leap or jump, especially a long or vigorous one.

**Meaning 3 (Adjective, Obligation/Certainty):** Obliged or compelled by duty, law, or circumstance; certain or very likely to happen.

**Meaning 4 (Adjective, Direction):** Heading toward or destined for a particular place or direction.

**Meaning 5 (Noun, Limit):** A line, point, or area that marks the extent or limit of something; a boundary.

**Meaning 6 (Verb, Limit):** To form the boundary of something; to limit or restrict.

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Movement, Constraint, Certainty, Location, Limit, Obligation

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
**Verb (Movement):**
  * Base: bound
  * Past Simple: bounded
  * Past Participle: bounded
  * Type: Intransitive (Vi) (Regular verb)

**Adjective (Obligation/Certainty & Direction):**
  * Form: bound (often functions as a past participle or is derived from one)
  * No comparative or superlative forms (as it's often a participle-like adjective).

**Noun (Movement & Limit):**
  * Plural: bounds

**Verb (Limit):**
  * Base: bound
  * Past Simple: bounded
  * Past Participle: bounded
  * Type: Transitive (Vt) (Regular verb)

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
**For meanings related to leaping (Verb, Noun):** This `bound` comes from Old French `bondir` 'to rebound, leap, spring', which itself derives from Vulgar Latin `*bombitīre` 'to buzz, hum', related to the sound of something striking or springing back. The meaning evolved to focus on the movement rather than the sound.

**For meanings related to obligation, certainty, or being tied (Adjective):** This `bound` is the past participle of the verb `bind`. It traces back to Old English `bindan` 'to tie, fasten', from Proto-Germanic `*bindaną`, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European `*bʰendʰ-` 'to tie, connect'.

**For meanings related to limits or boundaries (Noun, Verb):** This `bound` originates from Old French `bonde` 'limit, boundary stone', which comes from Late Latin `bodina` 'boundary'.

**For meanings related to direction or destination (Adjective):** This `bound` is derived from Old Norse `búinn` 'ready, prepared', which is the past participle of `búa` 'to prepare, dwell'. Its meaning evolved from 'prepared for a journey' to 'on the way to a specified place' in English.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. The gazelle bounded gracefully across the open savanna. (Movement Verb)
2. She felt bound by her promise to help him, even though it was inconvenient. (Obligation Adjective)
3. The train was bound for London, carrying hundreds of passengers. (Direction Adjective)
4. Beyond the bounds of the town, the landscape became wild and untamed. (Limit Noun)
5. The river broadly bounds the property on the western side. (Limit Verb)
6. He was bound to make a mistake eventually, given his carelessness. (Certainty Adjective)

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
*   **out of bounds:** Beyond a permitted or desirable area; forbidden or inappropriate. (Relates to Limit Noun)
*   **bound to happen:** Certain or inevitable to occur. (Relates to Certainty Adjective)
*   **bound and determined:** Resolute and highly motivated to achieve something. (Relates to Obligation Adjective)
*   **by leaps and bounds:** Very quickly and significantly; with great progress. (Relates to Movement Noun)

title: boundary
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /ˈbaʊndəri/
Pronunciation Key:
  /b/ as in 'bat'
  /aʊ/ as in 'cow'
  /n/ as in 'nap'
  /d/ as in 'dog'
  /ə/ as in 'about' (schwa)
  /r/ as in 'red'
  /i/ as in 'happy'

Definitions:
1. A line, mark, or imaginary point that defines the extent or limit of an area, territory, or domain, separating one space from another.
2. A limit or restriction on behavior, communication, or scope, serving to distinguish what is acceptable or permissible.

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Geography, Limits, Rules, Relationships, Abstract Concepts

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Noun
Plural form: boundaries

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The word 'boundary' emerged in Middle English as *boundaree*, a variation of *bounde*, meaning 'limit' or 'border'. *Bounde* itself was borrowed from Old French *bonne*, which also meant 'limit' or 'boundary'. The Old French term is believed to have Germanic origins, possibly from a Frankish word related to 'banna' (an area of jurisdiction or proclamation). The suffix '-ary' was later added by analogy with words like 'tertiary'. The core meaning related to a dividing line or limit has been preserved throughout its history.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. The river serves as a natural boundary between the two countries.
2. It's important for friends to establish clear boundaries in their personal interactions.
3. The artist consistently pushed the boundaries of traditional painting techniques.
4. Children often test the boundaries set by their parents to understand limits.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
*   **Cross the boundary:** To go beyond an established limit, rule, or acceptable range.
*   **Push the boundaries:** To extend the limits of what is possible, acceptable, or conventional.

title: bow
content:
There are two main pronunciations for 'bow', each with distinct meanings:

1.  **Pronunciation 1: /boʊ/ (rhymes with 'go')**
    Phonetic Transcription: /boʊ/
    Pronunciation Key:
      /b/ as in 'bat'
      /oʊ/ as in 'boat'
    Definitions:
    *   **Noun:** A weapon consisting of a flexible strip of wood or other material, bent by a string connecting its ends, used for shooting arrows.
    *   **Noun:** A knot with two loops, typically formed in a ribbon or string, often used for decorative purposes or tying.
    *   **Noun:** A thin rod with horsehair stretched between its ends, used to play stringed musical instruments.
    *   **Noun:** The front part of a ship or boat.

2.  **Pronunciation 2: /baʊ/ (rhymes with 'cow')**
    Phonetic Transcription: /baʊ/
    Pronunciation Key:
      /b/ as in 'bat'
      /aʊ/ as in 'cow'
    Definitions:
    *   **Verb (intransitive or transitive):** To bend the body or head forward as a gesture of respect, greeting, acknowledgment, or submission.
    *   **Noun:** An act of bending the head or body forward, especially as a gesture of respect or courtesy.
    *   **Verb (often with 'down', intransitive):** To yield or submit to pressure, a difficult situation, or someone's authority or will.

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Weapons, Fastenings, Music, Nautical, Gestures, Respect, Submission, Movement, Compliance

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
For /boʊ/ (noun): Part of speech: Noun. Plural form: bows.

For /baʊ/ (verb/noun): Part of speech: Verb (intransitive and transitive), Noun. Principal parts (Verb): base 'bow', past simple 'bowed', past participle 'bowed' (regular verb). Plural form (Noun): bows.

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Both pronunciations of 'bow' share a common linguistic ancestry, stemming from Old English terms that signified 'bending' or 'anything bent'. The /boʊ/ pronunciation (referring to a weapon, knot, or ship's front) derives from Old English *boga* (arch, bow, anything bent), which comes from Proto-Germanic *bugon-*. The /baʊ/ pronunciation (referring to the act of bending the body) comes from Old English *būgan* (to bend, to bow, to turn), from Proto-Germanic *bugana*. Both Proto-Germanic roots ultimately trace back to the Proto-Indo-European root *bheug-/*bhug-, meaning 'to bend' or 'to cause to bend'. The slight variations in form and pronunciation evolved over centuries, leading to the distinct modern meanings.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
For /boʊ/ (noun):
1.  He skillfully aimed the arrow from his bow at the target.
2.  She tied her hair back with a pretty satin bow.
3.  The violinist drew the bow across the strings to produce a rich sound.
4.  The waves crashed against the bow of the ship, sending spray high into the air.

For /baʊ/ (verb/noun):
1.  The audience applauded as the performers bowed deeply at the end of the show.
2.  She gave a slight bow before addressing the queen, showing respect.
3.  Despite the immense pressure, he refused to bow to public opinion and stuck to his principles.
4.  The old tree branch bowed under the heavy weight of the snow.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
For /boʊ/ (noun):
*   **Bow tie:** A type of necktie tied in a symmetrical knot around the collar, resembling a bow.
*   **A bow in the road:** A bend or curve in a road.

For /baʊ/ (verb):
*   **Bow out:** To withdraw from a situation, competition, or activity, often gracefully.
*   **Take a bow:** To acknowledge applause or recognition by bowing.
*   **Bow one's head in shame:** To lower one's head as a sign of disgrace, regret, or humility.

title: breach
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /briːtʃ/
Pronunciation Key:
  /b/ as in 'bat'
  /r/ as in 'red'
  /iː/ as in 'sheep' (long 'ee' sound)
  /tʃ/ as in 'church'

Definitions:
1. (noun) A gap, rupture, or opening in a wall, barrier, or defensive line, typically caused by damage or force.
2. (noun) An act of breaking or failing to observe a law, agreement, promise, or code of conduct.
3. (verb) To make a hole or gap in something, especially a physical barrier or defense.
4. (verb) To break or fail to keep a rule, agreement, or promise; to violate a commitment.
5. (verb, of a whale) To leap clear of the water's surface.

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Damage, Conflict, Law, Agreements, Failure, Obstacles, Marine Biology

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Noun, Verb (transitive and intransitive)
Plural form (Noun): breaches
Principal parts (Verb): base 'breach', past simple 'breached', past participle 'breached' (regular verb)

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: 'Breach' comes from Old French *breche*, meaning 'a gap', 'break', or 'rupture'. This Old French word is believed to have derived from a Germanic source, such as Frankish *breka* or Old High German *brehhan*, both related to the concept of 'to break'. Ultimately, it traces back to the Proto-Germanic *brekanan*, and further to the Proto-Indo-European root *bhreg-*, meaning 'to break'. The various meanings of 'breach' consistently revolve around the idea of a break or a violation.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. The enemy forces exploited the breach in the castle wall to gain entry.
2. His failure to deliver the goods on time constituted a clear breach of contract.
3. The demolition crew had to breach the old concrete barrier before they could proceed.
4. The company was accused of breaching environmental regulations by dumping waste.
5. During our whale watching trip, we saw a magnificent humpback whale breach the surface.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
*   **Breach of peace:** A violation of public order or tranquility, often involving disorderly conduct.
*   **Breach of trust:** An act of violating the confidence or faith that has been placed in someone.
*   **Breach of promise:** Failure to fulfill a commitment, often specifically referring to a commitment to marry (now largely archaic in this context).

title: breakdown
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /ˈbreɪkˌdaʊn/
Pronunciation Key:
  /b/ as in 'bat'
  /r/ as in 'red'
  /eɪ/ as in 'day'
  /k/ as in 'cat'
  /d/ as in 'dog'
  /aʊ/ as in 'cow'
  /n/ as in 'nap'

Definitions:
1. A mechanical failure or malfunction of a machine, vehicle, or system, causing it to stop functioning.
2. A collapse in mental or physical health, often characterized by severe emotional distress, exhaustion, or inability to cope.
3. A complete failure or collapse of a system, relationship, negotiation, or social order.
4. A detailed analysis, classification, or enumeration of something into its constituent parts or elements.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Noun
Plural form: breakdowns

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: 'Breakdown' is a compound noun formed from the verb 'break' and the adverb/preposition 'down'. The verb 'break' originates from Old English *brecan* (to shatter, destroy), tracing back through Proto-Germanic *brekanan* to the Proto-Indo-European root *bhreg-* (to break). The term 'breakdown' first appeared in the late 19th century in the sense of 'mechanical failure'. The meaning of 'mental collapse' developed in the early 20th century, and the sense of 'detailed analysis' (breaking something down into parts) followed as a logical extension.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. Our car had a breakdown on the highway, forcing us to call for assistance.
2. The immense pressure of her job led to a complete emotional breakdown.
3. The peace talks ended in a total breakdown after neither side would compromise.
4. The financial report provided a detailed breakdown of the company's expenses for the last quarter.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: *   **Suffer a nervous breakdown:** To experience a period of severe mental illness or emotional distress that significantly impairs one's ability to function normally (often shortened to 'breakdown' in this context).

title: breakthrough
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /ˈbreɪkˌθruː/
Pronunciation Key:
  /b/ as in 'bat'
  /r/ as in 'red'
  /eɪ/ as in 'day'
  /k/ as in 'cat'
  /θ/ as in 'thin' (voiceless 'th' sound)
  /r/ as in 'red'
  /uː/ as in 'moon' (long 'oo' sound)

Definitions:
1. A sudden, dramatic, and important discovery or advancement, especially in scientific research or technological development.
2. An act of overcoming a major obstacle or achieving significant progress after a period of difficulty.
3. In a military context, an instance where an attacking force successfully penetrates and passes through an enemy's defensive line.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Noun
Plural form: breakthroughs

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: 'Breakthrough' is a compound word derived from the verb 'break' and the preposition 'through'. 'Break' originates from Old English *brecan* (to shatter, destroy), linked to Proto-Germanic *brekanan* and ultimately to the Proto-Indo-European root *bhreg-* (to break). 'Through' comes from Old English *þurh* (through), from Proto-Germanic *thurkh*. The military sense of 'breaking through enemy lines' emerged in the early 20th century, particularly during World War I. The broader meaning of a 'significant discovery' or 'progress' developed later, metaphorically extending from this initial military usage.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. Scientists are hoping for a major breakthrough in cancer treatment research this decade.
2. After weeks of stalled negotiations, the team finally achieved a breakthrough with the client.
3. The general ordered the tanks to attempt a breakthrough at the weakest point of the enemy's defenses.
4. Developing a vaccine in such a short time was an incredible breakthrough in medical science.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: No widely recognized common idioms or fixed phrases distinct from the word's direct meanings. It primarily functions as a standalone noun or within compound noun phrases.

title: breed
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /briːd/
Pronunciation Key:
  /b/ as in 'bat'
  /r/ as in 'red'
  /iː/ as in 'sheep' (long 'ee' sound)
  /d/ as in 'dog'

Definitions:
1. (verb, transitive or intransitive) To produce offspring; to reproduce or cause animals to reproduce, especially through controlled mating.
2. (verb, transitive) To keep and raise animals or plants for specific purposes, often for profit, selective characteristics, or conservation.
3. (noun) A specific group of animals (or sometimes plants) within a species, developed by selective breeding and sharing distinct characteristics.
4. (verb, transitive) To give rise to; to cause something to happen or develop, especially something undesirable.
5. (noun, usually with 'of') A particular kind, type, or class of person or thing.

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Reproduction, Animals, Plants, Classification, Cause/Effect, Types

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Verb (transitive and intransitive), Noun
Principal parts (Verb): base 'breed', past simple 'bred', past participle 'bred' (irregular verb)
Plural form (Noun): breeds

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: 'Breed' originates from Old English *brēdan*, meaning 'to nourish', 'cherish', 'bring up', or 'to procreate'. It stems from the Proto-Germanic *brodjanan*, which meant 'to warm', 'keep warm', or 'to brood'. This etymological connection highlights the original sense of nurturing and incubation. Over time, the meaning evolved from 'raise offspring' to 'reproduce' and later, the noun sense of a specific group of animals sharing traits emerged.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. Rabbits breed very quickly, producing multiple litters each year.
2. He decided to breed horses for racing, focusing on developing fast and strong offspring.
3. Golden Retrievers are a popular dog breed known for their friendly and gentle temperament.
4. His constant complaining tends to breed resentment among his colleagues.
5. She represents a new breed of entrepreneur, combining business acumen with social responsibility.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
*   **Breed like rabbits:** To reproduce very rapidly and in large numbers.
*   **A dying breed:** Something or someone that is becoming increasingly rare, obsolete, or no longer common.

title: brick
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /brɪk/
Pronunciation Key:
  /b/ as in 'bat'
  /r/ as in 'red'
  /ɪ/ as in 'sit'
  /k/ as in 'cat'

Definitions:
1. (noun) A block of hardened clay or other ceramic material, typically rectangular, used as a fundamental building material in construction.
2. (noun, informal) A good, reliable, or honest person, often used in the phrase 'a brick' as a term of endearment or admiration.
3. (verb, transitive) To build, pave, or seal something using bricks.
4. (noun, informal, technology) An electronic device that has become completely unresponsive and unusable due to software or hardware failure, akin to a useless, heavy block.

details.label: Region
details.value: Common English (informal senses, 'drop a brick' more British)

details.label: Style
details.value: Common, Informal (for some senses), Construction, Technology (for 'bricked')

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Building Materials, Solidity, Reliability, Failure, Technology

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Noun, Verb (transitive)
Plural form (Noun): bricks
Principal parts (Verb): base 'brick', past simple 'bricked', past participle 'bricked' (regular verb)

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: 'Brick' entered English from Middle French *brique*, which itself likely came from Middle Dutch *bricke*, meaning 'a tile' or 'a brick'. The ultimate origin is somewhat uncertain, but it may be related to words signifying 'broken pieces of clay' or simply 'a block'. The core meaning as a building material has been consistent for centuries. The informal senses, such as referring to a reliable person or a broken electronic device, are more recent, metaphorical extensions of the word's primary meaning of solidity or unresponsiveness.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. The old Victorian house was built entirely of sturdy red bricks.
2. You can always count on Sarah in a crisis; she's a real brick.
3. They decided to brick up the old fireplace opening to improve insulation.
4. My phone was completely bricked after the failed software update, making it unusable.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
*   **Hit the brick wall:** To encounter an insurmountable obstacle or problem that prevents further progress.
*   **Like a ton of bricks:** With great force, impact, or suddenness.
*   **Brick by brick:** Slowly and methodically, building or achieving something gradually over time.
*   **Drop a brick (British English, informal):** To say something tactless, embarrassing, or inappropriate without intending to.

title: briefly
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /ˈbriːfli/
Pronunciation Key:
  /b/ as in 'bat'
  /r/ as in 'red'
  /iː/ as in 'sheep' (long 'ee' sound)
  /f/ as in 'fan'
  /l/ as in 'leaf'
  /i/ as in 'happy'

Definitions:
1. For a short period of time; in a quick or fleeting manner.
2. In a concise or succinct manner; using few words or providing only essential details.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Adverb
Comparative form: more briefly
Superlative form: most briefly

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: 'Briefly' comes from Middle English *brefly*, formed from the adjective 'brief' and the Old English adverbial suffix *-lice* (meaning 'like' or 'in the manner of'). The adjective 'brief' itself was borrowed from Old French *brief* (meaning 'short' or 'concise'), which ultimately traces back to the Latin word *brevis*, meaning 'short', 'small', or 'narrow'. The core meaning of referring to brevity in terms of time or expression has been consistent since its early forms.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. The sun appeared briefly through the clouds before it started raining again.
2. The manager spoke briefly about the new company policy, then opened the floor for questions.
3. She visited her old hometown briefly during her road trip down the coast.
4. To put it briefly, we need to significantly improve our customer service.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: No widely recognized common idioms or fixed phrases where 'briefly' contributes a meaning beyond its direct adverbial sense of 'for a short time' or 'in a few words'.

title: broadband
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /ˈbrɔːdbænd/
Pronunciation Key:
  /b/ as in 'bat'
  /r/ as in 'red'
  /ɔː/ as in 'saw' (long 'o' sound)
  /d/ as in 'dog'
  /b/ as in 'bat'
  /æ/ as in 'cat'
  /n/ as in 'nap'
  /d/ as in 'dog'

Definitions:
1. (noun) A high-capacity data transmission method that allows multiple signals or a wide range of frequencies to be sent over a single medium simultaneously, enabling very fast internet access.
2. (adjective) Relating to or characteristic of this high-speed data transmission technology or the services it provides.

details.label: Style
details.value: Technical, Common (in everyday usage for internet)

details.label: Frequency
details.value: Very common (especially in relation to internet service)

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Noun, Adjective
Plural form (Noun): broadbands (less common; often used as a mass noun or in an attributive adjective sense)
Adjective: No comparative or superlative forms, as it describes a specific technological category.

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: 'Broadband' is a compound word formed from 'broad' and 'band'. 'Broad' comes from Old English *brād* (meaning 'broad' or 'flat'), stemming from Proto-Germanic *braidaz*. 'Band' in this context (referring to a range of frequencies) comes from Old French *bande* (meaning 'strip' or 'ribbon'), ultimately from the Proto-Germanic verb *bindanan* (to bind). The term 'broadband' was first used in the mid-20th century within telecommunications to describe systems capable of handling a wide range of frequencies. Its widespread application and common usage in relation to high-speed internet access became prominent in the late 1990s and early 2000s.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. Our new office requires a high-speed broadband connection for all employees.
2. Many rural areas still lack reliable broadband internet access, creating a digital divide.
3. The government is investing heavily in expanding broadband infrastructure across the country.
4. Is your home equipped with a fibre optic broadband line, or do you use DSL?

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: No widely recognized common idioms or fixed phrases where 'broadband' contributes a meaning beyond its direct, technical sense.

title: broadcaster
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /ˈbrɔːdˌkæstər/ (American English); /ˈbrɔːdˌkɑːstə/ (British English)
Pronunciation Key:
  /b/ as in 'bat'
  /r/ as in 'red'
  /ɔː/ as in 'saw' (long 'o' sound)
  /d/ as in 'dog'
  /k/ as in 'cat'
  /æ/ as in 'cat' (American English) or /ɑː/ as in 'father' (British English)
  /s/ as in 'sit'
  /t/ as in 'top'
  /ə/ as in 'about' (schwa)
  /r/ as in 'red' (pronounced in rhotic accents like American English; silent in non-rhotic accents like British English)

Definitions:
1. A person who presents or comments on programs for radio or television; a reporter or presenter within the media industry.
2. A company or organization that transmits programs, news, or entertainment via radio or television to the public.

details.label: Region
details.value: Common English (with slight pronunciation variations between US/UK)

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Noun
Plural form: broadcasters

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: 'Broadcaster' is formed from the verb 'broadcast' and the agent noun suffix '-er'. The verb 'broadcast' originally meant 'to scatter seeds widely' (combining 'broad' and 'cast'). In the early 20th century, with the invention of radio technology, the meaning was metaphorically extended to refer to the wide dissemination of information or entertainment via radio waves. The noun 'broadcaster', referring to a person or entity engaged in this activity, emerged around the 1920s as radio became a mainstream medium.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. The experienced broadcaster delivered the evening news with a calm and authoritative voice.
2. Many independent broadcasters struggle to compete with large, established media corporations.
3. She dreams of becoming a television broadcaster and reporting from around the world.
4. The national public broadcaster announced a special program series for the upcoming holidays.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: No widely recognized common idioms or fixed phrases where 'broadcaster' contributes a meaning beyond its direct noun sense.

title: broadly
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /ˈbrɔːdli/

Pronunciation Key:

  • /b/ as in 'bat'
  • /r/ as in 'red'
  • /ɔː/ as in 'thought' (long 'o' sound)
  • /d/ as in 'dog'
  • /l/ as in 'love'
  • /i/ as in 'happy' (long 'e' sound)

Definitions:

  1. In a general or comprehensive manner, without focusing on minor details; widely.
  2. In a way that covers a wide scope or range.
  3. With a wide facial expression, typically a smile.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Adverb

Comparative: more broadly

Superlative: most broadly

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
Derived from Middle English 'brodly' or 'broadly', which combines 'brod' (meaning 'broad') with the adverbial suffix '-ly'. The word 'brod' itself originates from Old English 'brād' (meaning 'wide' or 'extensive'), which traces further back to Proto-Germanic `*braidaz`.

The meaning has consistently referred to wide scope, generality, or physical extent.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
• The two parties agreed broadly on the need for reform, but disagreed on the specifics.
  • Her research broadly examines the socioeconomic impacts of climate change in urban areas.
  • He smiled broadly, clearly pleased with the unexpected news.
  • Looking broadly at the market trends, we anticipate significant growth next quarter.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
• Broadly speaking: A phrase used to introduce a general statement that is true in most cases, but may have exceptions.
  • Speak broadly: To discuss a topic in a general way, without delving into specific details or nuances.

title: browser
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /ˈbraʊzər/

Pronunciation Key:

  • /b/ as in 'bat'
  • /r/ as in 'red'
  • /aʊ/ as in 'cow' (diphthong, 'ow' sound)
  • /z/ as in 'zoo'
  • /ər/ as in 'teacher' (schwa + r sound)

Definitions:

  1. (Computing) A software application used to access and view content on the World Wide Web, such as web pages, images, and videos.
  2. A person who casually looks through books, merchandise, or information without a specific intent to purchase or find something particular.
  3. An animal that feeds on leaves, twigs, or other vegetation that is typically higher off the ground, as opposed to grazing on grass.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Noun

Plural: browsers

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
Formed by adding the agent noun suffix '-er' to the verb 'browse'. The verb 'browse' comes from Old French 'broster' (meaning 'to sprout' or 'to eat young shoots'), which itself likely originated from a Germanic root.

The meaning evolved from an animal feeding on foliage to a person leisurely examining goods, and subsequently, in the digital age, to software that allows users to 'browse' information on the internet.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
• Most people use a web browser like Firefox or Chrome to access online content.
  • The bookstore was filled with browsers enjoying the quiet atmosphere and new releases.
  • Giraffes are well-known browsers, stretching their long necks to reach leaves high in the trees.
  • She spent an hour as a browser in the art gallery, appreciating each painting without rushing.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: • No widely recognized idioms or fixed phrases for this specific word.

title: brutal
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /ˈbruːtl/

Pronunciation Key:

  • /b/ as in 'bat'
  • /r/ as in 'red'
  • /uː/ as in 'moon' (long 'oo' sound)
  • /t/ as in 'top'
  • /l/ as in 'love'

Definitions:

  1. Extremely harsh, violent, and lacking any form of compassion or refinement.
  2. Unpleasantly severe or difficult to endure.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Adjective

Comparative: more brutal

Superlative: most brutal

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
Originates from Late Latin 'brutalis', meaning 'senseless', 'irrational', or 'crude'. This word itself is derived from Latin 'brutus', which signified 'heavy', 'dull', 'stupid', and later 'brute' (referring to a beast).

The English word adopted the sense of being animal-like in its lack of reason, especially in terms of extreme cruelty or severity.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
• The detective described the crime scene as a brutal act of violence.
  • The winter storm was particularly brutal, with freezing temperatures and heavy snowfall.
  • She delivered her feedback with brutal honesty, but it was exactly what he needed to hear.
  • The coach demanded a brutal training regimen from his athletes to prepare for the championship.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: • Brutal honesty: Truthfulness that is direct and often harsh, delivered without any attempt to soften the impact or be polite.

title: buck
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /bʌk/

Pronunciation Key:

  • /b/ as in 'bat'
  • /ʌ/ as in 'cup' (short 'u' sound)
  • /k/ as in 'cat'

Definitions:

  1. (Noun) The male of certain animals, particularly deer, antelope, hares, and rabbits.
  2. (Noun, Informal, US) A dollar bill; a unit of U.S. currency.
  3. (Verb) To resist or oppose something forcefully, often going against a prevailing trend or expectation.
  4. (Verb, Of a horse) To make a sudden jump with the back arched and the head down, kicking out with the hind legs, typically to dislodge a rider.
  5. (Noun, Informal) A sudden, abrupt movement or change in direction, often forceful.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Noun, Verb

Nouns:

  • Plural: bucks

Verbs:

  • Base: buck
  • Past Simple: bucked
  • Past Participle: bucked
  • Transitivity: Can be both transitive (Vt) as in 'buck the trend' and intransitive (Vi) as in 'the horse bucked'.

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
Noun (male animal): Traces back to Old English 'bucc' (meaning 'he-goat' or 'male deer'), which comes from Proto-Germanic `*bukkaz`.

Noun (dollar): Its origin is less certain, possibly stemming from 'buckskin' used as a medium of exchange in the 18th century, or related to the phrase 'buck-horn knife' which was used to cut playing cards.

Verb (resist/jump): Likely evolved from an unrecorded Old English word related to the noun for a 'ram' or 'goat', implying a forceful thrust or opposition. Also potentially influenced by Dutch 'bokken' (to butt).

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
• We saw a magnificent buck with large antlers standing near the forest edge.
  • Can you lend me twenty bucks until payday?
  • The company decided to buck the industry trend and invest heavily in sustainable energy.
  • The rodeo rider skillfully managed to stay on despite the bull's powerful buck.
  • She decided to buck conventional wisdom and start her own business.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
• Pass the buck: To shift responsibility or blame to someone else, avoiding it oneself.
  • Buck up: To cheer up; to become more courageous or optimistic, especially in a difficult situation.
  • Buck the trend: To act or behave in a way that goes against the prevailing or common tendency.
  • A quick buck: Money earned quickly and often easily, sometimes implying that it was gained without much effort or by questionable means.

title: buddy
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /ˈbʌdi/

Pronunciation Key:

  • /b/ as in 'bat'
  • /ʌ/ as in 'cup' (short 'u' sound)
  • /d/ as in 'dog'
  • /i/ as in 'happy' (long 'e' sound)

Definitions:

  1. (Noun) A close friend or companion.
  2. (Noun) A partner with whom one shares an activity or task, often for mutual support or safety.
