sections.content:
From Old French *excellence* 'superiority, merit, renown.'
Derived from Latin *excellentia* 'superiority, merit,' from *excellens*, present participle of *excellere* 'to rise above, surpass,' from *ex* 'out' + *cellere* 'to rise, project' (related to *collis* 'hill').
The root idea is of rising above others in quality.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
The restaurant strives for excellence in all its dishes.
Her commitment to excellence is evident in her meticulous work.
The university is renowned for its academic excellence.
Achieving excellence requires continuous effort and dedication.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: Par excellence: (French origin, but common in English) Being the best of a particular kind; quintessential. (e.g., 'He is a storyteller par excellence.')

title: exception
content:
/ɪkˈsɛpʃən/

Pronunciation Key:
/ɪ/ as in 'bit'
/k/ as in 'cat'
/s/ as in 'sit'
/ɛ/ as in 'bed'
/p/ as in 'pen'
/ʃ/ as in 'she'
/ə/ as in 'sofa'
/n/ as in 'no'

Definition:
1. Something that does not fit into a general rule or principle; an instance or case that deviates from the norm.
2. The act of excluding or leaving out something.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Noun
Plural: exceptions

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
From Old French *excepcion* (modern French *exception*) 'objection, reservation.'
Derived from Latin *exceptiō* 'an exception, objection,' from *exceptus*, past participle of *excipere* 'to take out, take up, exclude,' from *ex* 'out' + *capere* 'to take.'
The meaning evolved from 'taking out' to 'that which is taken out' or 'excluded,' hence something that stands apart.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
Everyone must complete the assignment; there will be no exceptions.
This type of bird is usually migratory, but this one is an exception.
With few exceptions, most of the students passed the exam.
The exception of certain clauses in the contract led to disagreement.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
With the exception of: Apart from; excluding.
Take exception to: To object strongly to something; to be offended by.
The exception that proves the rule: A stated exception calls attention to the existence of a general rule.

title: exceptional
content:
/ɪkˈsɛpʃənl̩/

Pronunciation Key:
/ɪ/ as in 'bit'
/k/ as in 'cat'
/s/ as in 'sit'
/ɛ/ as in 'bed'
/p/ as in 'pen'
/ʃ/ as in 'she'
/ə/ as in 'sofa'
/n/ as in 'no'
/l̩/ syllabic 'l' as in 'bottle'

Definition:
1. Outstanding or extraordinary; unusually good or excellent.
2. Unusual and not typical; forming an exception.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Adjective
Comparative: more exceptional
Superlative: most exceptional

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
Formed in English from *exception* + *-al* (adjective suffix).
Root is the same as *exception*: Latin *excipere* 'to take out, exclude.'
Initially meant 'constituting an exception,' and later developed the positive connotation of 'being exceptionally good.'

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
Her exceptional talent in music was evident from a young age.
The team showed exceptional teamwork during the final match.
He delivered an exceptional speech that moved the entire audience.
Under exceptional circumstances, we might consider the request.
It's an exceptional case that doesn't fit the general pattern.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: No particularly common idioms or fixed phrases.

title: excess
content:
/ˈɛksɛs/ (N), /ɪkˈsɛs/ (Adj/Adv, less common)

Pronunciation Key:
/ɛ/ as in 'bed'
/k/ as in 'cat'
/s/ as in 'sit'
/ɪ/ as in 'bit' (for the second syllable in noun)
/ə/ as in 'sofa' (schwa, sometimes for adjective)

Definition:
1. (N) An amount of something that is more than necessary, permitted, or desirable; a surplus.
2. (N) Immoderate or unrestrained behavior, especially in eating or drinking.
3. (Adj, often attributive) More than is needed; additional.

details.label: Style
details.value: Neutral, can be slightly formal for 'in excess of' or for moral connotations of 'excesses.'

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Noun, Adjective
Nouns: Plural: excesses
Adjectives: Often used as a modifier, no comparative/superlative forms as an adjective itself in this sense.

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
From Old French *exces* (modern French *excès*) 'overabundance, transgression.'
Derived from Latin *excessus* 'a going out or forth, a departure; a transgression, an immoderate action,' from *excedere* 'to go out, go beyond' (same root as *exceed*).
The meaning has consistently revolved around going beyond a limit, whether in quantity or behavior.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
The company produced an excess of goods, leading to a surplus.
Remove any excess glue before it dries completely.
After the party, there was a huge excess of food.
He was warned about his excesses and told to moderate his lifestyle.
Living a life of excess can lead to various problems.
You'll have to pay for excess luggage at the airport.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
In excess of: More than; above. (e.g., 'The bill was in excess of $500.')
To excess: To an immoderate or extreme degree. (e.g., 'He drinks to excess.')
Excess fat/weight: Surplus body fat/weight.

title: excessive
content:
/ɪkˈsɛsɪv/

Pronunciation Key:
/ɪ/ as in 'bit'
/k/ as in 'cat'
/s/ as in 'sit'
/ɛ/ as in 'bed'
/s/ as in 'sit'
/ɪ/ as in 'bit'
/v/ as in 'van'

Definition:
More than is necessary, normal, or reasonable; immoderate or inordinate.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Adjective
Comparative: more excessive
Superlative: most excessive

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
From Old French *excessif* (modern French *excessif*) 'immoderate.'
Derived from Latin *excessivus*, from *excessus*, past participle of *excedere* 'to go out, go beyond' (same root as *exceed*, *excess*).
The meaning has consistently pointed to something that surpasses appropriate bounds.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
The punishment seemed excessive for such a minor offense.
She felt excessive pressure to perform well in the competition.
Avoid excessive exposure to the sun during peak hours.
The project was delayed due to excessive bureaucracy.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: No particularly common idioms or fixed phrases, though it combines frequently with nouns (e.g., 'excessive force', 'excessive noise').

title: exclude
content:
/ɪkˈskluːd/

Pronunciation Key:
/ɪ/ as in 'bit'
/k/ as in 'cat'
/s/ as in 'sit'
/k/ as in 'cat'
/l/ as in 'light'
/uː/ as in 'moon'
/d/ as in 'dog'

Definition:
1. To prevent someone or something from being included in, participating in, or entering a place or group.
2. To rule out the possibility of something; to prevent from happening.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Verb (Vt)
Principal Parts: exclude (base), excluded (past simple), excluded (past participle)
Forms: Regular verb.

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
From Latin *exclūdere* 'to shut out, keep out, hinder,' from *ex* 'out' + *claudere* 'to shut.'
The meaning has remained consistent with the idea of keeping something outside a boundary or group.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
Children under 12 are excluded from this event.
The price excludes tax and shipping costs.
We must exclude any data that doesn't meet our criteria.
The evidence seemed to exclude the possibility of an accident.
Her strong alibi excludes her from being a suspect.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: No particularly common idioms or fixed phrases, though often used with prepositions (e.g., 'exclude from').

title: exclusion
content:
/ɪkˈskluːʒən/

Pronunciation Key:
/ɪ/ as in 'bit'
/k/ as in 'cat'
/s/ as in 'sit'
/k/ as in 'cat'
/l/ as in 'light'
/uː/ as in 'moon'
/ʒ/ as in 'measure'
/ə/ as in 'sofa'
/n/ as in 'no'

Definition:
1. The act of preventing someone or something from being included or from entering.
2. The state of being kept out or omitted.
3. Something that is excluded.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Noun
Plural: exclusions

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
From Latin *exclusio* (stem *exclusion-*) 'a shutting out, exclusion,' from *exclusus*, past participle of *excludere* 'to shut out' (same root as *exclude*).
The meaning directly follows from the verb.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
The policy led to the exclusion of many qualified candidates.
Her strict dietary regimen involved the exclusion of all processed foods.
He felt a profound sense of exclusion from the social group.
The document clearly states the terms of exclusion.
The contract lists several specific exclusions.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: Mutual exclusion: A principle in computer science or logic where two or more events or states cannot occur at the same time.

title: exclusive
content:
/ɪkˈskluːsɪv/ or /ɪkˈskluːzɪv/ 

Pronunciation Key:
/ɪ/ as in 'bit'
/k/ as in 'cat'
/s/ as in 'sit'
/k/ as in 'cat'
/l/ as in 'light'
/uː/ as in 'moon'
/s/ as in 'sit'
/z/ as in 'zoo' (alternative)
/ɪ/ as in 'bit'
/v/ as in 'van'

Definition:
1. (Adj) Restricted to a single person, group, or organization; not shared or available to others.
2. (Adj) Not admitting other things; leaving no room for other possibilities.
3. (Adj) High-class, expensive, or fashionable, indicating a select group of people.
4. (N) An item or story published or broadcast by only one news organization, usually obtained as a scoop.

details.label: Style
details.value: Neutral, can be positive (for luxury/status) or negative (for elitism, in Def 3).

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Adjective, Noun
Adjectives: Comparative: more exclusive; Superlative: most exclusive
Nouns: Plural: exclusives

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
From Medieval Latin *exclusivus* 'tending to exclude.'
Derived from Latin *exclusus*, past participle of *excludere* 'to shut out' (same root as *exclude*, *exclusion*).
The meaning evolved from 'serving to exclude' to 'being excluded' or 'being for an excluded few,' hence its connotations of restricted access or high status.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
The club operates on an exclusive membership basis.
They have an exclusive agreement with that supplier.
This offer is exclusive to our online customers.
Our research proves the theory, to the exclusion of all others.
They held the party at an exclusive downtown restaurant.
She shops at very exclusive boutiques.
The reporter secured an exclusive interview with the celebrity.
That newspaper often breaks exclusives about political scandals.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
To the exclusion of: Without including; leaving out. (e.g., 'He focuses on his studies to the exclusion of all social activities.')
Mutually exclusive: Not able to occur at the same time or be true at the same time.

title: exclusively
content:
/ɪkˈskluːsɪvli/
    Pronunciation Key: /ɪ/ as in 'kit', /k/ as in 'cat', /s/ as in 'snake', /l/ as in 'leaf', /uː/ as in 'moon', /s/ as in 'sit', /ɪ/ as in 'bit', /v/ as in 'van', /l/ as in 'love', /i/ as in 'happy'.

    1.  Used solely for one specific purpose or by a single individual or group, with no other inclusion or sharing.
    2.  Limited to only what is mentioned, without anything else being involved or considered.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Adverb
Comparative: More exclusively
Superlative: Most exclusively

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: From English `exclusive` combined with the adverbial suffix `-ly`. The word `exclusive` derives from Latin `exclusivus`, meaning 'serving to exclude'. This in turn comes from the Latin verb `excludere`, meaning 'to shut out, cut off', formed from `ex-` ('out') and `claudere` ('to shut').

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  This premium service is offered exclusively to our loyal customers.
2.  Her diet consists almost exclusively of organic vegetables and fruits.
3.  The designer works exclusively with sustainable materials.
4.  The new feature is exclusively available on the latest software update.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: No common idioms or fixed phrases use 'exclusively' as their primary component; it typically modifies verbs or adjectives within broader expressions.

title: execute
content:
/ˈɛksɪkjuːt/
    Pronunciation Key: /ɛ/ as in 'bed', /k/ as in 'cat', /s/ as in 'sit', /ɪ/ as in 'bit', /k/ as in 'kite', /j/ as in 'yes', /uː/ as in 'moon', /t/ as in 'top'.

    1.  (Vt) To carry out or perform a plan, instruction, or task, bringing it to completion.
    2.  (Vt) To put someone to death, especially as a legal punishment determined by a court.
    3.  (Vt) To create or perform a piece of art, music, or a maneuver according to its design or instructions.
    4.  (Vt) To formally sign and complete a legal document, making it valid and legally binding.

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Action, Performance, Law, Justice, Arts, Computing

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Verb (Vt - Transitive)
Principal Parts: execute (base), executed (past simple), executed (past participle)
Forms: executes, executing

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Derived from Old French `executer`, meaning 'to carry out, perform, fulfill'. This comes from the Latin `executare`, a variant of `exsequi`, which meant 'to follow out, follow up, pursue, carry out'. `Exsequi` is composed of `ex-` ('out') and `sequi` ('to follow'). The specific meaning of 'to put to death' emerged in English in the 15th century, evolving from the general sense of 'carrying out a judicial sentence'.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The project manager was tasked with making sure the team could execute the strategy on time.
2.  Historically, rulers would often execute individuals accused of treason.
3.  The pianist expertly executed the complex musical passage with great skill.
4.  Before closing the deal, both parties needed to execute the final contract.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1.  **Execute a program/code (Computing):** To run computer instructions or software.
    *   *Example: The technician needed to execute a diagnostic program to find the error.*
2.  **Execute a turn (Sports/Driving):** To perform a specific turning maneuver with precision.
    *   *Example: The race car driver expertly executed the tight turn on the final lap.*

title: execution
content:
/ˌɛksɪˈkjuːʃən/
    Pronunciation Key: /ɛ/ as in 'bed', /k/ as in 'cat', /s/ as in 'sit', /ɪ/ as in 'bit', /k/ as in 'kite', /j/ as in 'yes', /uː/ as in 'moon', /ʃ/ as in 'shoe', /ə/ as in 'about', /n/ as in 'nut'.

    1.  The act or process of carrying out or performing a plan, task, or order.
    2.  The legal act of putting a condemned person to death as a punishment.
    3.  The manner or quality in which something is performed or done, often referring to skill or style.
    4.  The formal signing and completion of a legal document, making it valid.

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Action, Performance, Law, Justice, Arts, Business

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Noun
Plural Form: executions

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Originates from Old French `execucion`, which comes from Latin `executionem` (nominative `executio`), meaning 'a carrying out, performing'. This noun is derived from the past participle `executus` of the verb `exsequi` ('to follow out, pursue, carry out'), related to the verb `execute`. The sense of 'infliction of capital punishment' became prominent in English around the late 14th century.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The successful execution of the marketing campaign led to increased sales.
2.  The country abolished capital punishment, ending all future executions.
3.  The artist's painting showed brilliant execution, particularly in the use of light.
4.  The lawyer was present for the execution of the new land deed.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1.  **Execution of a will/document:** The formal legal act of making a document valid and binding by signing and fulfilling all requirements.
    *   *Example: The family gathered for the execution of the will after the reading.*
2.  **Flawless execution:** Performing a task or plan perfectly, without any mistakes or errors.
    *   *Example: The gymnast's routine was a masterpiece of flawless execution.*

title: exert
content:
/ɪɡˈzɜːrt/ (American English), /ɪɡˈzɜːt/ (British English)
    Pronunciation Key: /ɪ/ as in 'bit', /ɡ/ as in 'go', /z/ as in 'zoo', /ɜːr/ as in 'bird' (American English), /ɜː/ as in 'bird' (British English), /t/ as in 'top'.

    1.  (Vt) To apply or bring to bear a force, influence, or pressure, typically with effort.
    2.  (Vt, often reflexive) To make a significant physical or mental effort; to apply oneself vigorously.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Verb (Vt - Transitive)
Principal Parts: exert (base), exerted (past simple), exerted (past participle)
Forms: exerts, exerting

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Comes from Latin `exserere`, meaning 'to put forth, thrust out, put out (from a row)'. This is formed from `ex-` ('out') and `serere` ('to join, link, arrange'). The specific English meaning of 'to put forth or use' (e.g., strength, influence, power) developed in the late 17th century.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The strong winds exerted immense force on the old oak tree.
2.  She had to exert considerable patience while teaching the new interns.
3.  The leader attempted to exert his authority over the dissenting factions.
4.  If you want to succeed, you must learn to exert yourself fully in your studies.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1.  **Exert oneself:** To make a significant physical or mental effort; to work hard.
    *   *Example: He had to exert himself to finish the marathon.*
2.  **Exert influence/pressure:** To use one's power or position to affect a situation or person.
    *   *Example: Lobbyists often try to exert influence on lawmakers.*

title: exhibit
content:
/ɪɡˈzɪbɪt/
    Pronunciation Key: /ɪ/ as in 'bit', /ɡ/ as in 'go', /z/ as in 'zoo', /ɪ/ as in 'kit', /b/ as in 'bat', /ɪ/ as in 'bit', /t/ as in 'top'.

    1.  (Vt) To display or show something publicly, often in a structured or formal setting like a museum or gallery.
    2.  (Vt) To show or demonstrate a quality, feeling, or behavior, often involuntarily.
    3.  (N) An item or collection of items displayed for public viewing, especially in a museum or at a fair.
    4.  (N, Law) A document or object presented as formal evidence in a court of law.

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Display, Show, Evidence, Behavior, Art, Law

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Verb (Vt - Transitive), Noun

Verb Principal Parts: exhibit (base), exhibited (past simple), exhibited (past participle)
Forms: exhibits, exhibiting

Noun Plural Form: exhibits

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Comes from Latin `exhibere`, meaning 'to hold out, present, show, display'. This verb is formed from `ex-` ('out') and `habere` ('to have, hold'). The noun sense in English developed later, in the 17th century.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The artist will exhibit her latest sculptures at the city's art fair.
2.  The patient began to exhibit symptoms of recovery after the treatment.
3.  The new museum exhibit explores the history of ancient civilizations.
4.  The attorney presented the signed contract as Exhibit B in the court case.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1.  **Exhibit A (informal):** A prime or clear example of something, often used in a slightly jocular or critical sense.
    *   *Example: His messy desk is Exhibit A of his disorganization.*

title: exile
content:
/ˈɛksaɪl/, /ˈɛɡzaɪl/ (both common)
    Pronunciation Key: /ɛ/ as in 'bed', /k/ as in 'cat', /s/ as in 'sit', /aɪ/ as in 'my', /l/ as in 'leaf' OR /ɡ/ as in 'go', /z/ as in 'zoo'.

    1.  (N) The state of being forced to live away from one's native country or home, often as a punishment or for political reasons.
    2.  (N) A person who has been expelled or banished from their native country.
    3.  (Vt) To banish or expel someone from their native country or home.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Noun, Verb (Vt - Transitive)

Noun Plural Form: exiles

Verb Principal Parts: exile (base), exiled (past simple), exiled (past participle)
Forms: exiles, exiling

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The noun comes from Old French `essil`, meaning 'banishment, expulsion', which in turn is from Latin `exsilium` ('banishment, exile'). This Latin term derived from `exsul`, meaning 'an exiled person, wanderer', composed of `ex-` ('out') and `solum` ('soil, ground, land'). The verb sense in English appeared later, in the 16th century.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  Many political opponents were forced into exile during the dictator's reign.
2.  He lived as an exile in a foreign land for decades, longing for his homeland.
3.  The government decided to exile the rebellious general from the country.
4.  She chose a life of self-imposed exile to pursue her artistic endeavors without distraction.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1.  **Self-imposed exile:** A situation where someone chooses to live away from their home country or community, rather than being forced to.
    *   *Example: After the scandal, he went into self-imposed exile in a remote cabin.*

title: exit
content:
/ˈɛksɪt/, /ˈɛɡzɪt/ (both common)
    Pronunciation Key: /ɛ/ as in 'bed', /k/ as in 'cat', /s/ as in 'sit', /ɪ/ as in 'bit', /t/ as in 'top' OR /ɡ/ as in 'go', /z/ as in 'zoo'.

    1.  (N) A way out of a place; a door, gateway, or passage that allows departure.
    2.  (N) The act of leaving a place, situation, or a dramatic performance.
    3.  (V) To go out of or leave a place.
    4.  (V, Theatre) To leave the stage during a play or performance.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Noun, Verb (Vi - Intransitive, Vt - Transitive)

Noun Plural Form: exits

Verb Principal Parts: exit (base), exited (past simple), exited (past participle)
Forms: exits, exiting

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: From Latin `exitus`, meaning 'a going out, a departure, a way out; an end, conclusion, result'. This noun is derived from the Latin verb `exire`, meaning 'to go out', which is composed of `ex-` ('out') and `ire` ('to go'). The verb sense in English appeared slightly after the noun.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The emergency exit was clearly marked with a green sign.
2.  His sudden exit from the company sparked rumors among employees.
3.  She quietly exited the room so as not to disturb the meeting.
4.  The actor made his grand exit from the stage to thunderous applause.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1.  **Make an exit:** To leave a place, often referring to the manner of leaving.
    *   *Example: He made a quick exit before anyone could ask him about the incident.*
2.  **Stage an exit:** To leave in a dramatic or noticeable way, often to draw attention.
    *   *Example: She staged an exit by slamming the door on her way out.*
3.  **Exit strategy:** A predetermined plan for leaving a project, difficult situation, or market.
    *   *Example: The company needs a clear exit strategy for their unsuccessful venture.*

title: exotic
content:
/ɪɡˈzɒtɪk/ (British English), /ɪɡˈzɑːtɪk/ (American English)
    Pronunciation Key: /ɪ/ as in 'bit', /ɡ/ as in 'go', /z/ as in 'zoo', /ɒ/ as in 'hot' (British English), /ɑː/ as in 'father' (American English), /t/ as in 'top', /ɪ/ as in 'kit', /k/ as in 'cat'.

    1.  (Adj) Originating in or characteristic of a distant foreign country or region.
    2.  (Adj) Attractively unusual, strikingly different, or intriguingly strange in appearance, sound, or nature.

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Origin, Appearance, Travel, Culture, Uniqueness, Attractiveness

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Adjective
Comparative: More exotic
Superlative: Most exotic

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Derived from Late Latin `exoticus`, meaning 'foreign'. This in turn comes from the Ancient Greek `exōtikos`, meaning 'foreign, outside', which itself is derived from `exō`, meaning 'outside, out of'.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The market was filled with exotic spices and colorful textiles from Asia.
2.  She always dreams of visiting exotic locations around the world.
3.  The zoo housed several exotic birds with vibrant plumage.
4.  He found her accent and mannerisms quite exotic and captivating.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: There are no widely recognized idioms or fixed phrases that primarily feature the word 'exotic'.

title: expansion
content:
/ɪkˈspænʃən/
    Pronunciation Key: /ɪ/ as in 'bit', /k/ as in 'cat', /s/ as in 'sit', /p/ as in 'pen', /æ/ as in 'cat', /n/ as in 'nut', /ʃ/ as in 'shoe', /ə/ as in 'about', /n/ as in 'nut'.

    1.  The act or process of increasing in size, volume, or extent.
    2.  An increase in the scope, range, or operations of a business, organization, or idea.
    3.  A part that has been added to something to make it larger or more extensive.

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Growth, Size, Business, Physics, Development, Increase

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Noun
Plural Form: expansions

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: From Latin `expansionem` (nominative `expansio`), meaning 'a spreading out'. This noun is derived from the Latin verb `expandere`, meaning 'to spread out, extend', which is formed from `ex-` ('out') and `pandere` ('to spread').

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The rapid expansion of the universe is a key concept in cosmology.
2.  The company announced a major expansion into overseas markets next year.
3.  The expansion of the library included a new wing and several reading rooms.
4.  The uncontrolled expansion of urban areas often leads to environmental challenges.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1.  **Business expansion:** The growth of a company's operations, market share, or physical presence.
    *   *Example: The board approved the budget for the new business expansion.*

title: expenditure
content:
/ɪkˈspɛndɪtʃər/ (American English), /ɪkˈspɛndɪtʃə/ (British English)
    Pronunciation Key: /ɪ/ as in 'bit', /k/ as in 'cat', /s/ as in 'sit', /p/ as in 'pen', /ɛ/ as in 'bed', /n/ as in 'nut', /d/ as in 'dog', /ɪ/ as in 'bit', /tʃ/ as in 'church', /ər/ as in 'teacher' (American English), /ə/ as in 'about' (British English).

    1.  The act of spending or using up money, time, or other resources.
    2.  The total amount of money, time, or resources spent on a particular purpose or during a specific period.

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Finance, Economics, Resources, Time, Management, Cost

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Noun
Plural Form: expenditures

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: From Anglo-French `expenditure`. It ultimately traces back to the Latin verb `expendere`, meaning 'to weigh out, pay out'. This verb is composed of `ex-` ('out') and `pendere` ('to weigh, hang').

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The new infrastructure project required a significant expenditure of public funds.
2.  We need to carefully monitor our daily expenditures to stay within budget.
3.  His constant expenditure of mental energy on trivial matters left him exhausted.
4.  Government expenditure on education has been increasing steadily over the past decade.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1.  **Capital expenditure (CapEx):** Money spent by a business or organization on acquiring or upgrading fixed assets, such as property, buildings, or equipment.
    *   *Example: The company's capital expenditure for the new factory was substantial.*
2.  **Operating expenditure (OpEx):** Money spent on the day-to-day running of a business or organization, such as salaries, utilities, and rent.
    *   *Example: Reducing operating expenditure is crucial for improving profit margins.*

title: experimental
content:
A phonetic transcription using the IPA (International Phonetic Alphabet): /ɪkˌspɛrɪˈmɛntl/

Pronunciation Key:
/ɪ/: as in "kit"
/k/: as in "cat"
/s/: as in "sit"
/p/: as in "pat"
/ɛ/: as in "bed"
/r/: as in "red"
/m/: as in "mat"
/n/: as in "nap"
/t/: as in "top"
/l/: as in "light"
/ˌ/: secondary stress
/ˈ/: primary stress

Definitions:
1.  Pertaining to, derived from, or involving the process of trying out new ideas, methods, or actions to discover something. It indicates an approach based on testing and observation.
2.  Still in the early stages of development or testing; not yet fully proven or established.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Adjective
Comparative: more experimental
Superlative: most experimental

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Traces back to Late Latin *experimentalis* (relating to experiment), which comes from Latin *experimentum* (a trial, test, proof). *Experimentum* is derived from *experiri* (to try, test, prove), formed from *ex-* (out) + *periri* (to try). *Periri* is ultimately linked to Proto-Indo-European *per-* (to try, risk). The meaning evolved directly from the concept of trying or testing something to understand its nature or effects.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The research team is conducting *experimental* studies to understand the new drug's long-term effects.
2.  Her latest art exhibition features *experimental* techniques, blending unusual materials and abstract forms.
3.  The company's self-driving car technology is still in an *experimental* phase, undergoing rigorous safety tests.
4.  They adopted an *experimental* approach to problem-solving, trying several new methods.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: While not a fixed idiom, "experimental stage" or "experimental phase" is a common collocation referring to a period of testing or development.

title: expertise
content:
A phonetic transcription using the IPA (International Phonetic Alphabet): /ˌɛkspərˈtiːz/

Pronunciation Key:
/ɛ/: as in "bed"
/k/: as in "cat"
/s/: as in "sit"
/p/: as in "pat"
/ər/: as in "bird" (non-rhotic) or "butter" (rhotic)
/t/: as in "top"
/iː/: as in "fleece"
/z/: as in "zoo"
/ˌ/: secondary stress
/ˈ/: primary stress

Definitions:
1.  Extensive skill, knowledge, or specialized judgment possessed by an individual in a particular field, typically acquired through training, experience, or study.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Noun
Plural: Often treated as a non-count noun (e.g., "valuable expertise"). In specific, formal contexts, "expertises" can be used to refer to distinct types or areas of specialized knowledge.

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Derived from French *expertise* (a specialist's report, expert appraisal), which comes from *expert*. *Expert* itself originates from Latin *expertus* (proven, tried, skilled), the past participle of *experiri* (to try, test). This shared root with "experimental" reflects the idea of someone who has been "tested" or "proven" in their abilities, leading to the meaning of professional knowledge.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The consultant was hired for her exceptional *expertise* in digital marketing strategies.
2.  Building a successful startup requires diverse *expertise* from various fields, including finance and technology.
3.  He shared his legal *expertise* to help guide the new non-profit organization.
4.  The team relied on her *expertise* in data analysis to interpret the complex results.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: “Area of expertise”: a specific subject or skill in which someone has specialized knowledge or skill.

title: expire
content:
A phonetic transcription using the IPA (International Phonetic Alphabet): /ɪkˈspaɪər/

Pronunciation Key:
/ɪ/: as in "kit"
/k/: as in "cat"
/s/: as in "sit"
/p/: as in "pat"
/aɪ/: as in "my"
/ər/: as in "bird" (non-rhotic) or "butter" (rhotic)
/ˈ/: primary stress

Definitions:
1.  (Of a period of time, a document, or a right) To reach its end or no longer be valid, typically at a predetermined point.
2.  (Formal, euphemistic) To cease to live; to die.

details.label: Style
details.value: General (for meaning 1), Formal, Literary, Euphemistic (for meaning 2)

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Verb
Principal Parts: expire, expired, expired
Transitivity: Intransitive (Vi)

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Originates from Old French *expirer* (to breathe out, die, run out), which comes from Latin *expirare* (to breathe out, exhale, die). This Latin verb is a compound of *ex-* (out) + *spirare* (to breathe), which is from Proto-Indo-European *speis-* (to blow, breathe). The literal meaning of "breathe out" directly led to the sense of "to die." The broader meaning of "to come to an end" evolved from this, likening the end of a life to the cessation of validity or a period of time.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  Your driver's license will *expire* at the end of next month, so remember to renew it.
2.  The warranty for the new appliance is set to *expire* in two years.
3.  As the day began to *expire*, the shadows lengthened across the field.
4.  (Formal) The aged monarch *expired* peacefully in her sleep after a long illness.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: While not a common idiom, "expire on" (a date) or "expire after" (a period) are common collocations used to specify when something ceases to be valid.

title: explicit
content:
A phonetic transcription using the IPA (International Phonetic Alphabet): /ɪkˈsplɪsɪt/

Pronunciation Key:
/ɪ/: as in "kit"
/k/: as in "cat"
/s/: as in "sit"
/p/: as in "pat"
/l/: as in "light"
/ɪ/: as in "kit"
/s/: as in "sit"
/t/: as in "top"
/ˈ/: primary stress

Definitions:
1.  Stated or expressed with utmost clarity and detail, leaving no room for misunderstanding or ambiguity.
2.  Describing or depicting potentially sensitive content (such as sexual activity or violence) in a direct, clear, and often graphic manner, which may be deemed inappropriate for certain audiences.

details.label: Style
details.value: General (for meaning 1), Often used in media ratings, legal, or social discussions (for meaning 2)

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Clarity, Communication, Information, Media, Morality, Content Rating

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Adjective
Comparative: more explicit
Superlative: most explicit

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: From Old French *explicite*, or directly from Latin *explicitus* (unfolded, unrolled, explained, clear). This is the past participle of Latin *explicare* (to unfold, unroll, disentangle, explain), which is formed from *ex-* (out) + *plicare* (to fold). *Plicare* comes from Proto-Indo-European *plek-* (to plait, fold). The meaning evolved from the idea of "unfolding" or "unrolling" something, making it clear and visible, leading to the modern sense of clarity and directness.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The project manager gave *explicit* instructions, detailing every step of the task.
2.  He provided an *explicit* warning about the dangers of crossing the flooded river.
3.  Parents are concerned about children being exposed to *explicit* content on the internet.
4.  The film received an adult rating due to its *explicit* depiction of violence.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: “Explicit consent”: a common legal and ethical collocation referring to permission that is clearly and directly given, often verbally or in writing.

title: explicitly
content:
A phonetic transcription using the IPA (International Phonetic Alphabet): /ɪkˈsplɪsɪtli/

Pronunciation Key:
/ɪ/: as in "kit"
/k/: as in "cat"
/s/: as in "sit"
/p/: as in "pat"
/l/: as in "light"
/ɪ/: as in "kit"
/s/: as in "sit"
/t/: as in "top"
/l/: as in "light"
/i/: as in "happy" (unstressed final /i/)
/ˈ/: primary stress

Definitions:
1.  In a manner that is clearly and unambiguously stated or expressed, leaving no uncertainty.
2.  In a way that directly and without reservation portrays or describes sensitive or controversial subject matter (e.g., sex or violence).

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Adverb
Comparative: more explicitly
Superlative: most explicitly

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Formed in English by adding the adverbial suffix *-ly* to the adjective *explicit*. It thus inherits the etymology of *explicit*, which comes from Latin *explicitus* (unfolded, explained), past participle of *explicare* (to unfold, explain), from *ex-* (out) + *plicare* (to fold). The addition of *-ly* transforms the adjective's meaning of clear and direct into an adverbial sense of doing something in a clear and direct manner.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The rules for the competition were *explicitly* written in the handbook.
2.  She *explicitly* stated that she would not tolerate any delays.
3.  The artist chose to *explicitly* represent the harsh realities of war in their new sculpture.
4.  The software is designed to *explicitly* block access to inappropriate content.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: No common idioms directly associated with "explicitly."

title: exploit
content:
A phonetic transcription using the IPA (International Phonetic Alphabet):
Verb: /ɪkˈsplɔɪt/
Noun: /ˈɛksplɔɪt/

Pronunciation Key (Verb):
/ɪ/: as in "kit"
/k/: as in "cat"
/s/: as in "sit"
/p/: as in "pat"
/l/: as in "light"
/ɔɪ/: as in "boy"
/t/: as in "top"
/ˈ/: primary stress

Pronunciation Key (Noun):
/ɛ/: as in "bed"
/k/: as in "cat"
/s/: as in "sit"
/p/: as in "pat"
/l/: as in "light"
/ɔɪ/: as in "boy"
/t/: as in "top"
/ˈ/: primary stress

Definitions:
**Verb**:
1.  To use someone or something in a way that is unfair, selfish, or morally wrong, often taking advantage of their vulnerability or resources.
2.  To make effective and full productive use of a resource, opportunity, or system to gain benefit.
3.  (Technical, computing) To take advantage of a flaw or vulnerability in a computer system or software to gain unauthorized access or control.

**Noun**:
1.  A notable or daring act; a remarkable feat or achievement, especially one involving courage or skill.

details.label: Style
details.value: General (for positive verb sense and noun), Negative/Critical (for negative verb sense), Technical (for computing sense)

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Resources, Labor, Ethics, Achievement, Technology, Security, Opportunity

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Verb (transitive - Vt), Noun

Verb Principal Parts: exploit, exploited, exploited
Noun Plural: exploits

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
The verb "exploit" comes from French *exploiter* (to bring to completion, to gain advantage from), which, like "explicit," derives from Latin *explicare* (to unfold, achieve). The meaning evolved from "unfolding" or "developing" a thing, leading to "bringing it to completion" and then "making use of it." 

The noun "exploit" comes from Old French *exploit* (a feat, success, profit), also deriving from Latin *explicitus* or *explicare*. The sense of "accomplishment" or "achievement" also stems from the idea of "bringing something to completion." The two parts of speech, though pronounced differently, share a common historical root in Latin and have evolved related but distinct meanings.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  (Verb) Many activists argue that fast-fashion companies *exploit* cheap labor in developing countries.
2.  (Verb) Engineers are working to *exploit* new renewable energy sources more efficiently.
3.  (Verb) Cybersecurity researchers aim to identify and patch vulnerabilities before malicious actors can *exploit* them.
4.  (Noun) The book recounted the daring *exploits* of the secret agent during the war.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: “Exploit a loophole”: to take advantage of an ambiguity or omission in a rule or law to gain an advantage.

title: exploitation
content:
A phonetic transcription using the IPA (International Phonetic Alphabet): /ˌɛksplɔɪˈteɪʃn/

Pronunciation Key:
/ɛ/: as in "bed"
/k/: as in "cat"
/s/: as in "sit"
/p/: as in "pat"

/ɔɪ/: as in "boy"
/t/: as in "top"
/eɪ/: as in "face"
/ʃ/: as in "shoe"
/n/: as in "nap"
/ˌ/: secondary stress
/ˈ/: primary stress

Definitions:
1.  The act or process of using someone or something unfairly for one's own gain, often involving moral wrongness or taking advantage of vulnerability.
2.  The action of fully and productively utilizing a resource or opportunity to derive benefit.
3.  (Technical, computing) The successful use of a weakness or vulnerability in a system or software to achieve an unintended or unauthorized outcome.

details.label: Style
details.value: General, Academic, Technical, often used in a critical or negative context

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Ethics, Resources, Labor, Human Rights, Technology, Security, Social Issues

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Noun
Plural: exploitations (less common, usually refers to distinct instances or types of exploitation)

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Comes from French *exploitation* (cultivation, working of a mine, a farming estate), which is derived from the French verb *exploiter* (to exploit). Ultimately, it shares the same Latin root as the verb "exploit" and "explicit": *explicare* (to unfold, achieve, make use of). The noun form directly signifies the process or result of exploiting, carrying both the negative sense of abuse and the neutral/positive sense of utilization, depending on the context of its use.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The documentary exposed the widespread *exploitation* of migrant workers in the agricultural sector.
2.  Sustainable *exploitation* of natural resources is essential for environmental preservation and economic growth.
3.  Cybersecurity experts are constantly working to prevent the *exploitation* of newly discovered software flaws.
4.  The community expressed strong opposition to the *exploitation* of local artists.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: “Child exploitation”: a common legal and social collocation referring to the abuse of children, often for commercial or sexual purposes.

title: explosive
content:
A phonetic transcription using the IPA (International Phonetic Alphabet): /ɪkˈspləʊsɪv/

Pronunciation Key:
/ɪ/: as in "kit"
/k/: as in "cat"
/s/: as in "sit"
/p/: as in "pat"
/l/: as in "light"
/əʊ/: as in "goat"
/s/: as in "sit"
/ɪ/: as in "kit"
/v/: as in "van"
/ˈ/: primary stress

Definitions:
**Adjective**:
1.  Having the capacity to burst violently and produce a sudden release of energy, typically with great force and noise; relating to such a burst.
2.  Likely to erupt suddenly and powerfully, often referring to emotions, situations, or rapid growth.

**Noun**:
1.  A substance or device specifically designed to cause a sudden, forceful, and noisy burst.

details.label: Style
details.value: General, Technical (for chemicals), Figurative (for temper, growth)

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Danger, Chemistry, Emotion, Growth, Conflict, Force

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Adjective, Noun

Adjective Comparative: more explosive
Adjective Superlative: most explosive
Noun Plural: explosives

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Derived from French *explosif*, which itself comes from Latin *explōsus*, the past participle of *explōdere*. The Latin *explōdere* originally meant "to drive out by clapping" or "to hiss off a stage." It was formed from *ex-* (out) + *plaudere* (to clap, applaud). Over time, the meaning of *explodere* shifted from a sense of rejection with noise to simply "burst forth with noise," eventually leading to the modern understanding of a violent, noisy bursting, and thus the development of "explosive."

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  (Adjective) The factory takes strict precautions when handling highly *explosive* chemicals.
2.  (Adjective) His *explosive* temper often made difficult situations even worse.
3.  (Noun) The bomb disposal squad carefully removed the *explosives* from the building.
4.  (Adjective) The new product experienced *explosive* growth in its first year on the market.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
“Explosive growth”: extremely rapid and significant increase or development.
“Explosive situation”: a tense or volatile circumstance that is likely to erupt into conflict or crisis.

title: exposure
content:
A phonetic transcription using the IPA (International Phonetic Alphabet): /ɪkˈspəʊʒər/

Pronunciation Key:
/ɪ/: as in "kit"

/əʊ/: as in "goat"
/ʒ/: as in "measure"
/ər/: as in "bird" (non-rhotic) or "butter" (rhotic)
/ˈ/: primary stress

Definitions:
1.  The condition of being subjected to or affected by something, particularly something potentially harmful or unpleasant, such as environmental conditions or dangerous substances.
2.  The act of revealing something hidden, secret, or previously unknown, especially something scandalous or discreditable.
3.  The state of being made visible, known, or observed by the public or a specific audience; visibility.
4.  (Photography) The amount of light that reaches a photographic film or sensor, determining the brightness of an image.

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Risk, Health, Revelation, Publicity, Art, Media, Light, Environment

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Noun
Plural: exposures

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Originates from Anglo-French *exposen*, which comes from Latin *exponere* (to set forth, explain, display, expose). This Latin verb is composed of *ex-* (out) + *ponere* (to place). The meaning evolved from the literal sense of "putting something out" or "setting something forth," leading to the ideas of revealing, making something vulnerable to external conditions, or making it public and visible.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  Prolonged *exposure* to direct sunlight can increase the risk of skin damage.
2.  The journalist's investigative reporting led to the *exposure* of widespread corruption in the city government.
3.  Young artists often seek *exposure* for their work in galleries and online platforms.
4.  The photographer adjusted the camera's *exposure* settings to capture the perfect balance of light and shadow.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
“Exposure to the elements”: the state of being subjected to harsh outdoor weather conditions like wind, rain, or cold.
“Lack of exposure”: insufficient experience with something or inadequate public visibility.

title: extension

Definitions:
1.  The act or process of making something longer, larger, or wider, or the condition of being stretched or enlarged.
2.  An additional part that is joined to something to make it bigger or longer.
3.  An additional period of time that is granted for completing something, such as a deadline.
4.  (Telecommunications) A separate telephone line connected to a main line, typically within a building.
5.  (Hairdressing) Artificial hair additions used to make natural hair appear longer or fuller.

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Size, Time, Addition, Structure, Communication, Beauty, Space

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Noun
Plural: extensions

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Derives from Late Latin *extensiōn-* (a stretching out), from Latin *extensiō*, which comes from *extendere* (to stretch out, extend). This Latin verb is formed from *ex-* (out) + *tendere* (to stretch), and *tendere* ultimately comes from Proto-Indo-European *ten-* (to stretch). The meaning has directly evolved from the physical act of stretching or making something longer to encompass various senses of adding to, enlarging, or prolonging something in time or space.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The library is planning an *extension* to its research wing to accommodate more books.
2.  I asked for an *extension* on my essay deadline due to unforeseen circumstances.
3.  Please contact me on *extension* 345 if you have any further questions.
4.  She got hair *extensions* for the wedding to add volume and length to her hairstyle.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
“By extension”: as a logical consequence or broader implication of something previously stated or understood.
“Extension cord”: a portable length of electric cable with a plug at one end and one or more sockets at the other, used to extend the reach of electrical power.

title: extensive
content:
Phonetic: /ɪkˈstɛnsɪv/

Pronunciation Key:
/ɪ/: as in "bit"
/k/: as in "cat"
/s/: as in "snake"
/t/: as in "top"
/ɛ/: as in "bed"

Definitions:
1. Covering a large area or having a wide scope.
2. Thorough and far-reaching; involving many details or a great deal of effort.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Adjective
Comparative: more extensive
Superlative: most extensive

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
Origin: Late Middle English, from Old French 'extensif', from Medieval Latin 'extensivus'.
Deep Origin: Derived from Latin 'extens-', the past participle stem of 'extendere' (to stretch out, spread out). This verb is formed from Latin 'ex-' (out) + 'tendere' (to stretch).
Proto-Indo-European (PIE) Root: Ultimately from the PIE root '*ten-' (to stretch).
Evolution: The meaning evolved from the physical act of stretching or spreading out to describe something that covers a wide area or is broad in scope or detail.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. The university library boasts an extensive collection of historical documents.
2. After years of extensive research, the team published their groundbreaking findings.
3. The damage from the recent storm was so extensive that entire neighborhoods required rebuilding.
4. She has extensive experience in international relations, making her an ideal candidate.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: There are no highly common idioms or fixed phrases specific to 'extensive'. It is typically used in a straightforward descriptive manner.

title: extensively
content:
Phonetic: /ɪkˈstɛnsɪvli/

Pronunciation Key:
/ɪ/: as in "bit"
/k/: as in "cat"
/s/: as in "snake"
/t/: as in "top"
/ɛ/: as in "bed"
/n/: as in "nap"
/v/: as in "van"
/l/: as in "light"
ˈ: indicates primary stress on the following syllable

Definitions:
1. To a great extent; over a wide area or scope.
2. In a thorough and far-reaching manner.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Adverb
Comparative: more extensively
Superlative: most extensively

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
Origin: Formed in English by adding the adverbial suffix '-ly' to the adjective 'extensive'.
Deep Origin: 'Extensive' itself traces back to Late Middle English, from Old French 'extensif', from Medieval Latin 'extensivus', derived from Latin 'extendere' (to stretch out, spread out), which combines 'ex-' (out) and 'tendere' (to stretch). The ultimate PIE root is '*ten-' (to stretch).
Evolution: The adverbial form simply applies the meaning of 'extensive' to describe how an action is performed, indicating a broad scope or thoroughness.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. The report discussed the environmental impact extensively.
2. She traveled extensively throughout Europe before starting her career.
3. The new policy was debated extensively by the committee members.
4. He has written extensively on the subject of artificial intelligence.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: There are no common idioms or fixed phrases specific to 'extensively'.

title: extract
content:
Phonetic: (Verb) /ɪkˈstrækt/, (Noun) /ˈɛkstrækt/

Pronunciation Key:
/ɪ/: as in "bit"
/k/: as in "cat"
/s/: as in "snake"
/t/: as in "top"
/r/: as in "red"
/æ/: as in "cat"
/ɛ/: as in "bed"
ˈ: indicates primary stress on the following syllable

Definitions:
Verb:
1. To remove or pull out something, especially with effort or force.
2. To obtain a substance or information from something else, often through a specific process or analysis.
3. To select and quote a passage or section from a text or recording.

Noun:
1. A substance obtained by drawing it out from a larger source, often in a concentrated or pure form.
2. A selected passage or quotation from a book, film, or piece of music.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Verb, Noun

Verb:
Base: extract
Past Simple: extracted
Past Participle: extracted
Type: Transitive (Vt)

Noun:
Plural: extracts

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
Origin: Late Middle English, from Latin 'extractus', the past participle of 'extrahere' (to draw out).
Deep Origin: 'Extrahere' is formed from Latin 'ex-' (out) + 'trahere' (to pull, draw).
Evolution: The meaning has remained very consistent from its Latin root, referring to the act of pulling something out, whether it's a physical object, a chemical substance, or information from a text.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
Verb:
1. The dentist had to extract the problematic wisdom tooth.
2. Scientists are working to extract the essential oil from the rare plant.
3. It's difficult to extract a clear meaning from such an ambiguous statement.
4. Please extract a few key paragraphs from the article for the summary.

Noun:
1. She added a teaspoon of vanilla extract to the cookie dough.
2. The student presented a brief extract from Shakespeare's play.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: There are no common idioms or fixed phrases specific to 'extract'.

title: extremist
content:
Phonetic: /ɪkˈstriːmɪst/

Pronunciation Key:

/k/: as in "cat"
/s/: as in "snake"

Definitions:
Noun:
1. A person who holds radical or unconventional political, religious, or social views, especially one who advocates or engages in extreme action to achieve their goals.

Adjective:
1. Characterized by radical, fanatical, or unconventional opinions or actions.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Noun, Adjective

Noun:
Plural: extremists

Adjective:
Comparative: more extremist
Superlative: most extremist

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
Origin: Early 20th century, formed in English by adding the suffix '-ist' (denoting a person who practices or believes in something) to the adjective 'extreme'.
Deep Origin: 'Extreme' comes from Latin 'extremus' (outermost, furthest, last, utmost), which is the superlative of 'exter' (on the outside). Latin 'exter' is related to 'ex-' (out of).
Evolution: The meaning of 'extreme' shifted from denoting a physical outermost point to an utmost degree or intensity. The term 'extremist' then emerged to describe individuals who hold views or advocate actions that are at the furthest limits of what is considered acceptable or moderate.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
Noun:
1. The government expressed concern about the rising influence of political extremists.
2. He was branded an extremist for his uncompromising stance on environmental issues.
3. Security forces monitored several known extremists planning public disturbances.

Adjective:
1. The group's extremist rhetoric drew widespread condemnation.
2. She was accused of holding extremist views on immigration.
3. The party's platform included several extremist proposals that alienated moderate voters.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: There are no common idioms or fixed phrases specific to 'extremist'.

title: fabric

Phonetic: /ˈfæbrɪk/

/r/: as in "red"

Definitions:
1. Cloth or other pliable material produced by weaving, knitting, or otherwise combining textile fibers.
2. The fundamental structure, framework, or underlying system of something, such as a building, society, or an argument.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Noun
Plural: fabrics (when referring to different types or pieces of cloth); often used as a mass noun (e.g., "much fabric").

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
Origin: Late Middle English, from Old French 'fabrique' (something constructed, building, structure).
Deep Origin: From Latin 'fabrica' (a workshop, art, craft, structure, the fabric of a building). 'Fabrica' is derived from 'faber' (craftsman).
Evolution: The word's primary meaning in English shifted from its earlier sense of 'structure' or 'construction' (which is still present in sense 2) to specifically refer to 'woven structure', i.e., cloth. This highlights a specialization from a general concept of building to a specific type of manufactured material.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. She chose a soft cotton fabric for the child's blanket.
2. The designer works with various fabrics, including silk, wool, and linen.
3. The scandal threatened to unravel the very fabric of society.
4. Architects analyzed the underlying fabric of the ancient Roman amphitheater.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1. `The fabric of society/life`: Refers to the basic structure, interconnected elements, and established norms that form a society or human existence.
   Example: "The widespread corruption began to erode the very fabric of the nation's governance."

title: fabulous
content:
Phonetic: /ˈfæbjələs/

Pronunciation Key:
/f/: as in "fan"
/æ/: as in "cat"
/b/: as in "bat"
/j/: as in "yes"

Definitions:
1. (Informal) Exceptionally good, impressive, or attractive; excellent.
2. Mentioned in or characteristic of fables or myths; legendary or mythical.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Adjective
Comparative: more fabulous
Superlative: most fabulous

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
Origin: Late 15th century, from Latin 'fabulosus' (celebrated in fable, legendary).
Deep Origin: 'Fabulosus' is derived from Latin 'fabula' (a story, tale, fable), which itself comes from 'fari' (to speak).
Evolution: The original meaning directly related to 'fables' or things existing in legends. The modern, informal sense of 'extremely good' or 'amazing' emerged in the mid-20th century. This semantic shift likely occurred because things described in fables are often extraordinary, leading to an exaggeration of the original meaning.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. We had a absolutely fabulous time at the beach yesterday.
2. The view from the top of the mountain was simply fabulous.
3. Dragons and unicorns are examples of fabulous creatures found in folklore.
4. He often told fabulous tales of his adventures in distant lands.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: There are no highly common idioms or fixed phrases unique to 'fabulous' beyond its direct descriptive use.

title: facilitate

Pronunciation Key:

Definitions:
1. To make an action or process easier or less difficult.
2. To help bring about or promote the progress of something.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Verb
Base: facilitate
Past Simple: facilitated
Past Participle: facilitated
Type: Transitive (Vt)

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
Origin: Early 17th century, from French 'faciliter'.
Deep Origin: From Latin 'facilis' (easy), which is derived from 'facere' (to make, to do).
Evolution: The word's meaning has consistently revolved around the concept of making something easier or more possible, directly reflecting its Latin root related to 'easy' and 'to make'.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. Good communication can greatly facilitate teamwork.
2. The new software will facilitate data sharing among different departments.
3. The coordinator worked to facilitate a smooth transition for the new employees.
4. Training courses are designed to facilitate skill development in the workforce.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: There are no common idioms or fixed phrases specific to 'facilitate'.

title: faction
content:
Phonetic: /ˈfækʃən/

Pronunciation Key:
/f/: as in "fan"
/æ/: as in "cat"
/k/: as in "cat"
/ʃ/: as in "shoe"

Definitions:
1. A small, organized, dissenting group within a larger one, especially in politics or an organization.
2. Conflict or discord that arises from within a group due to opposing views or interests.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Noun
Plural: factions

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
Origin: Early 16th century, from French 'faction' (a party, a clique).
Deep Origin: From Latin 'factio(n-)' (a political party or group, a company of gladiators, a making, a doing). 'Factio' is derived from 'facere' (to make, to do).
Evolution: The Latin root 'factio' initially referred to the act of doing or making, and by extension, a group that acts together. In Roman times, it specifically designated political parties or racing stables. In English, the meaning solidified to a group that often creates division or conflict within a larger body.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. The ruling party was deeply divided into several warring factions.
2. Disagreements among the small factions threatened to derail the peace talks.
3. Within the literary club, a new faction emerged advocating for modern poetry.
4. The leader tried to unite the disparate factions into a cohesive movement.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: There are no common idioms or fixed phrases specific to 'faction'.

title: faculty
content:
Phonetic: /ˈfækəlti/

Pronunciation Key:
/f/: as in "fan"
/æ/: as in "cat"
/k/: as in "cat"
/ə/: as in "sofa" (schwa)
/l/: as in "light"
/t/: as in "top"
/i/: as in "happy" (unstressed 'ee' sound)
ˈ: indicates primary stress on the following syllable

Definitions:
1. An inherent mental or physical ability or power of the body (e.g., the faculty of sight or reason).
2. A department or group of related departments within a university.
3. The entire teaching staff of a university or college, or a specific department.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Noun
Plural: faculties

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
Origin: Late Middle English, from Old French 'faculte'.
Deep Origin: From Latin 'facultas' (ability, skill, opportunity, means). 'Facultas' is derived from 'facil-' (easy), which is related to 'facere' (to do, to make).
Evolution: The original meaning related to 'ability' or 'capacity' (still present in sense 1). This extended to a 'branch of knowledge' (like a university department) because such branches require specific abilities or provide the means to acquire them. From there, it further broadened to refer to the 'body of teachers' within such a branch or institution.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. Despite his age, his mental faculties remained remarkably sharp.
2. The university's Faculty of Engineering is renowned for its research.
3. All members of the faculty are invited to the annual commencement ceremony.
4. The human body possesses the incredible faculty of self-healing.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: There are no highly common idioms or fixed phrases specific to 'faculty'.

title: fade
content:
Phonetic: /feɪd/

Pronunciation Key:
/f/: as in "fan"
/eɪ/: as in "day"
/d/: as in "dog"

Definitions:
1. (Of a color, light, or sound) to gradually grow less bright, intense, or audible; to diminish in vividness or strength.
2. (Of a memory, feeling, or presence) to gradually disappear or become indistinct.
3. To lose freshness, vigor, or strength over time.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of Speech: Verb
Base: fade
Past Simple: faded
Past Participle: faded
Type: Intransitive (Vi) and Transitive (Vt)

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
Origin: Late Middle English, from Old French 'fader' (to become weak, grow faint).
Deep Origin: Likely from a Germanic source related to Old English 'fæd' (pale, faded), and possibly ultimately from Proto-Germanic '*faidaz' (pale, dull).
Evolution: The core meaning has consistently been about a gradual reduction in intensity, color, sound, or presence, reflecting the idea of becoming dull or faint.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. The old photographs had faded in the sunlight over many years. (Vi)
2. As the sun set, the bright colors of the sky began to fade. (Vi)
3. The sound of the train whistle slowly faded into the distance. (Vi)
4. Too much exposure to the sun can quickly fade the colors of your curtains. (Vt)
5. Over time, the painful memories began to fade. (Vi)

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1. `Fade out`: To gradually disappear or become inaudible/invisible.
   Example: "The music began to fade out as the credits rolled."
2. `Fade away`: To gradually diminish, become less noticeable, or disappear completely.
   Example: "His hopes of winning the championship slowly faded away."
3. `Fade into the background`: To become less prominent, important, or noticeable.
   Example: "After the initial excitement, the issue faded into the background."

title: federal
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /ˈfɛdərəl/

Pronunciation Key:
/f/ as in "fan"
/ɛ/ as in "bed"
/d/ as in "dog"
/ə/ as in "about" (schwa)
/r/ as in "red"
/l/ as in "light"

Definitions:
1.  (Adjective) Pertaining to a system of government where power is formally divided between a central national authority and various regional or state-level governing bodies.
2.  (Adjective) Relating to or supporting the central government of a federation.
3.  (Adjective) Formed by or based on an agreement or treaty between constituent units.

details.label: Region
details.value: Common English (especially American English for political context)

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Adjective
Comparative: more federal
Superlative: most federal

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Originates from Late Latin 'foedalis', meaning 'relating to a league or treaty'. This term derives from Latin 'foedus', which refers to a 'treaty, league, or covenant'. The Latin 'foedus' is thought to stem from a Proto-Indo-European root, possibly '*bʰeidʰ-', meaning 'to trust' or 'to entrust'. The meaning evolved from simply pertaining to an agreement to specifically describing a political system based on a union or alliance of states under a central authority.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The federal government allocates funds to various state-level programs.
2.  Australia operates under a federal system, dividing powers between the Commonwealth and states.
3.  The agency launched a federal investigation into the widespread fraud.
4.  They discussed the need for a more federal structure within the European Union.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: No common idioms or fixed phrases specifically using 'federal'.

title: feeding
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /ˈfiːdɪŋ/

Pronunciation Key:
/f/ as in "fan"
/iː/ as in "see"
/d/ as in "dog"
/ɪ/ as in "kit"
/ŋ/ as in "sing"

Definitions:
1.  (Noun) The act or process of providing nourishment, sustenance, or a meal to someone or something.
2.  (Noun) The act of supplying something with necessary input or material.
3.  (Verb, Present Participle) The ongoing action of providing food or nourishment; consuming food.
4.  (Verb, Present Participle) The ongoing action of supplying or inserting material into a machine or process.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Noun (gerund), Verb (present participle)

For Noun:
Plural: feedings (e.g., 'multiple feedings')

For Verb:
Base form: feed
Past simple: fed
Past participle: fed
Transitivity: Can be Transitive (Vt) or Intransitive (Vi)
- Vt: 'She is feeding the baby.'
- Vi: 'The baby is feeding well.'
Forms are irregular.

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The word 'feeding' is the present participle and gerund form of the verb 'feed'. 'Feed' comes from Old English 'fēdan', meaning 'to nourish, sustain, provide food for, eat'. This, in turn, is derived from Proto-Germanic '*fōdjanan' (to provide with food), which is related to '*fōdō' (food). The ultimate root is believed to be Proto-Indo-European '*pah₂-d-' (to protect, pasture, feed). The meaning has remained consistent over centuries, referring to the act of giving or consuming food.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The veterinarian gave instructions on the proper feeding of the new puppy. (Noun)
2.  Automated feeding systems are common in modern livestock farms. (Noun)
3.  The mother was busy feeding her newborn child. (Verb)
4.  The machine requires constant feeding of raw materials to operate efficiently. (Verb)

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1.  **Feeding frenzy:** A situation where a large number of people or animals aggressively pursue something, often competitively or with intense excitement.
2.  **Feeding time:** A designated period when animals, especially in zoos or on farms, are given their food.

title: feminist
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /ˈfɛmənɪst/

Pronunciation Key:
/f/ as in "fan"
/ɛ/ as in "bed"
/m/ as in "mat"
/ə/ as in "about" (schwa)
/n/ as in "nut"
/ɪ/ as in "kit"
/s/ as in "sit"
/t/ as in "top"

Definitions:
1.  (Noun) A person who advocates for or supports the social, political, economic, and personal equality of the sexes.
2.  (Adjective) Relating to or characterized by the principles of feminism.

details.label: Semantic Fields
details.value: Politics, Social Movements, Gender Studies, Activism

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Noun, Adjective

For Noun:
Plural: feminists

For Adjective:
Comparative: more feminist
Superlative: most feminist

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The word 'feminist' originated in the late 19th century. It is derived from the French word 'féministe', which was coined in the 1870s by the utopian socialist Charles Fourier, though its popular use began later. The French term was formed from 'femme' (woman), from Latin 'femina', combined with the suffix '-iste' (equivalent to English '-ist'), which denotes a person who practices or believes in something. Its adoption into English marked the rise of organized movements advocating for women's rights.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  She proudly declared herself a feminist, committed to achieving gender parity. (Noun)
2.  Many young people today identify as feminist, advocating for intersectional equality. (Noun)
3.  The novel offers a compelling feminist critique of societal norms. (Adjective)
4.  He supported several feminist initiatives aimed at empowering women in leadership roles. (Adjective)

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: No common idioms or fixed phrases specifically using 'feminist'.

title: fever
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /ˈfiːvər/

Pronunciation Key:
/f/ as in "fan"
/iː/ as in "see"
/v/ as in "van"
/ər/ as in "butter" (r-colored schwa, for rhotic accents; /ə/ in non-rhotic accents)

Definitions:
1.  (Noun) An abnormally high body temperature, typically a symptom of illness or infection.
2.  (Noun) A state of extreme excitement, agitation, or nervous anticipation.
3.  (Noun) A strong, often obsessive, enthusiasm or craze for something.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Noun
Plural: fevers

Note: While less common, 'fever' can occasionally be used as a verb in a literary or archaic context, meaning 'to cause to have a fever' or 'to become feverish'. (e.g., 'The illness began to fever him.')
Base: fever
Past simple: fevered
Past participle: fevered
Transitivity: Transitive (Vt) or Intransitive (Vi)
Forms are regular.

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The word 'fever' comes from Old English 'fēfer', which was borrowed from Latin 'febris', meaning 'fever'. The Latin 'febris' is related to 'fovēre' (to warm, to heat). This Latin root is thought to derive from a Proto-Indo-European root '*dʰegʷʰ-' (to burn, to be warm). The core meaning of elevated body temperature has remained central, while metaphorical senses of intense excitement or enthusiasm developed later, reflecting the intense physical sensation associated with illness.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The child had a high fever, so we took him to the doctor. (Meaning 1)
2.  A gold rush gripped the town, creating a fever of excitement. (Meaning 2)
3.  The election campaign generated a real fever among the supporters. (Meaning 3)
4.  She felt a low fever coming on and decided to rest. (Meaning 1)

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1.  **Fever pitch:** The highest point of intensity or excitement.
2.  **Catch a fever:** To become ill with a fever.
3.  **Gold fever:** An intense desire for gold, often leading to a rush or migration (historical context).

title: fibre
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /ˈfaɪbər/

Pronunciation Key:
/f/ as in "fan"
/aɪ/ as in "my"
/b/ as in "bat"
/ər/ as in "butter" (r-colored schwa, for rhotic accents; /ə/ in non-rhotic accents)

Definitions:
1.  (Noun) A thread-like structure or natural filament, especially one suitable for making textiles or composite materials.
2.  (Noun) Dietary material from plant cells that cannot be digested by the human body but is beneficial for bowel function.
3.  (Noun) The fundamental character or essence of something, often implying strength or resilience.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Noun
Plural: fibres

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The word 'fibre' comes from Old French 'fibre', directly from Latin 'fibra', meaning 'fiber, filament, entrails'. The ultimate origin of the Latin word is uncertain, but it might be related to Proto-Indo-European '*bʰei-' (to strike, to split), referring to something that can be split into threads. The meaning has largely retained its core sense of a thread-like material, expanding into biological and metaphorical uses over time.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The garment was made from natural cotton fibres. (Meaning 1)
2.  Eating enough dietary fibre is essential for good digestion. (Meaning 2)
3.  The politician lacked the moral fibre to stand up to corruption. (Meaning 3)
4.  Optical fibre cables transmit data at incredibly high speeds. (Meaning 1)

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: 1.  **Moral fibre:** The inherent strength of character and principles that allows one to act ethically and resist temptation.

title: fierce
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /fɪərs/ (RP), /fɪrs/ (GA)

Pronunciation Key:
/f/ as in "fan"
/ɪə/ as in "near" (RP)
/ɪr/ as in "mirror" (GA)
/s/ as in "sit"

Definitions:
1.  (Adjective) Displaying an intense, hostile, and aggressive nature, often in a menacing or violent way.
2.  (Adjective) Very strong, powerful, or intense in action or effect.
3.  (Adjective) Showing passionate determination or enthusiasm.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Adjective
Comparative: fiercer
Superlative: fiercest

Adverb form: fiercely

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The word 'fierce' comes from Middle English 'fers' or 'feers', which was borrowed from Old French 'fiers' (masculine) or 'fiere' (feminine), meaning 'proud, strong, brave, wild, cruel'. This Old French term originated from Latin 'ferus', meaning 'wild, untamed, savage'. The Latin 'ferus' is from a Proto-Indo-European root '*gʰwer-' meaning 'wild beast'. The meaning has remained consistent in conveying a sense of wildness, intensity, and strength, extending from literal untamed animals to powerful natural forces and human emotions.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  A fierce dog guarded the entrance to the property. (Meaning 1)
2.  The storm unleashed a fierce wind that battered the coast. (Meaning 2)
3.  She fought with fierce determination to win the championship. (Meaning 3)
4.  There is fierce competition for places in the top universities. (Meaning 2)

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: No common idioms or fixed phrases specifically using 'fierce'.

title: film-maker
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /ˈfɪlmˌmeɪkər/

Pronunciation Key:
/f/ as in "fan"
/ɪ/ as in "kit"
/l/ as in "light"
/m/ as in "mat"
/eɪ/ as in "day"
/k/ as in "cat"
/ər/ as in "butter" (r-colored schwa, for rhotic accents; /ə/ in non-rhotic accents)

Definitions:
1.  (Noun) A person who directs or produces films, often also involved in writing, editing, and other aspects of motion picture creation.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part of speech: Noun
Plural: film-makers (also 'filmmakers' is common, increasingly replacing the hyphenated form)

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: The word 'film-maker' is a compound noun formed from 'film' and 'maker'. 'Film' originated in Old English 'filmen', meaning 'membrane, thin skin', related to 'fell' (animal hide). This sense evolved to refer to the thin coating of photographic material and then to motion pictures. 'Maker' comes from Old English 'macian' (to make, to create), from Proto-Germanic '*makōną'. The compound 'film-maker' emerged in the early 20th century as the motion picture industry developed, literally meaning 'one who makes films'.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1.  The independent film-maker struggled to secure funding for her latest project.
2.  Akira Kurosawa is considered one of the greatest film-makers in history.
3.  Aspiring film-makers often start with short amateur videos.
4.  The festival attracts a diverse group of international film-makers each year.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: No common idioms or fixed phrases specifically using 'film-maker'.

title: filter
content:
Phonetic Transcription: /ˈfɪltər/

Pronunciation Key:
/f/ as in "fan"
/ɪ/ as in "kit"
/l/ as in "light"
/t/ as in "top"
/ər/ as in "butter" (r-colored schwa, for rhotic accents; /ə/ in non-rhotic accents)

Definitions:
